content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a review for the build up to this point. I will write something more comprehensive when it's at release. This game has an absolutely fantastic shell for a great game. The gameplay feels wonderful, the textures and visuals are top notch, the simplistic yet addictive item/loot/stats systems all work. The random generation of worlds is passable (although still could about ten times as many prefab chunks. HOWEVER.It's extremely light on content. I don't know if that's because they are leaving that to last, however i blew though this game in 18 minutes. And I did not rush. I did die about 20 times before I finished it, so my total playtime is a few hours. That is still absolutely horrible compared to ANY other game of this type out there. Even very cheaply made games like rouge shooter have 100 times more content than this game. It needs more levels. Bigger levels. More items, more scaling. Etc. It's like a demo version of a game. And I am kind of scared that they are just going to tweak systems until release, instead of releasing actual game length. The game needs to be streatched across a wider canvas, make the drops scale very slowly upwards, make the levels huge with multi areas leading to the floor down, so we can explore sprawling levels if we wish, instead of these tinny little dungeons. Right now, because this game has the core mechanics of a 10/10 indie game. I am going to recommend this game. However if the content is the same as it is now, at release. Then I'll be changing my recommendation.

number of helpful: 49 of 61 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
Early Access Review
								Amazing mix of a 2D Dungeon RPG (think Link to the Past for SNES) and Doom. The game starts you with a random inventory (one weapon, one food, one magic item, and some gold) and you can talk to a few NPCs to hear about the dangerous dungeon ahead. You head inside and explore the dungeon killing enemies and collecting progressively better loot until eventually, you die. When you respawn, thinking that all hope is lost, you realize that your gold from your previous life is still with you. You also realize, going into the dungeon, that it's different each time. The Camp where the npcs live in the beginning has many shops and the dungeon is endless and randomly generated. You can collect and save your gold to buy better loot in the town or just find as much as you can before you're killed in the dungeon. No matter how you play, delver is a great, addictive, cheap and fun retro dungeon-adventure game that everyone should play ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------OTHER REASONS TO BUYEpic Pixel GraphicsLevel EditorStill in Beta (so much more to come)its CHEAP (4 dollars when i bought it, normally 8)----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------EVERYONE TRY DELVER!

Early Access Review
								EDIT Jul 21, 2016: The developers are still working on the game, it has not been abandoned as many users fear. You can follow @joshuaskelly on Twitter for more frequent mini-updates about the progress of the game.Delver is a fun roguelike with a lot of potential. Still has some kinks and bugs that need ironing out, some balancing issues, et cetera, but it's Early Access for a reason, so you shouldn't let that deter you much. The game also comes with the easy-to-use editor to make your own areas/levels for the creative types. You should definitely give this game a try if you're into roguelikes.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing. Been playing it since it was in it's Alpha stages and was free and since then this game has improved A TON. Every run is randomly generated and you never know what you're going to find or have to go up against. Every level you go gets harder and harder and if you don't have very good gear or arnt leveled up alot, then you're not going to last very long (Especially on the trip back.) The replayability of this game is great too. It hasnt gotten old and I have yet to beat it. (The trip back is extremely hard if you don't have alot of HP pots, Good wands and really good armor.) I give it a 9/10. Definitely worth my $8.PS: This game is still in beta, but the Devs seem to have some great ideas coming up like shops, more levels, classes and other things. So if you're worried about content, stop worrying. There's alot more to come and this game has a ton of potential.EDIT: (11/30/2014) The game is still being updated and is still improving drastically. With the addition of 2 hand slots and destructable boxes along with a ton of new room layouts (Namely the caves, they've been completely re-done to look 100 times better.) Everything i've said before still stands and i'd still reccomend getting this. It's a great buy!

number of helpful: 28 of 29 people (97%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm no fan of early access games, but actually, this one is a definite exception to the rule. I got this in the Roguelike 2 Humble Bundle (so it was something like £4 for this and other rougelikes), but this was the game I was looking forward to. I'll quickly list some pros, cons, and then my experience.Pro:• Really good combat system with a focus on timing (nice balance of annoying bats and poison worms, and non-annoying enemies).• Levelling up and getting loot works well. You sometimes get a rare piece of kit, which makes you feel like god for a few floors.• Very attractive game (although there  could be a little room for improvement in some of the room details), chunky pixels are officially cool. The first, second and final themes work really well. The third theme is a little pedestrian - and so dark you just can't see anything in it.• Music is great, very fitting but not in-your-face-y.Con:• Foremost: almost all of the game is just so dark. There needs to be a 'Scroll of Light', or an update making the Candle light up the world a little more. In the third 'theme' (I won't spoil it), it's so dark that you often can't see any monsters, especially as only a few pixels aren't hiding in the water.• Jesus christ, the poison goes on for years.• Very little point in not choosing to level up HP when you get the choice. I went from 8HP to 38HP (ish) in one run-through, and if you wear the armour you just find, you basically don't need to worry. If you don't, then the poison (above) will easily kill you.• No way to block with your shield? And also, 2handed weapons don't seem to do any more damage, to make up for not having a shield? And - equipping books as a shield feels like it should do something, but no notes anywhere make it clear what (if anything) having a book equipped does.• Regardless of the above things: I finished the game in my first run-through. If you can't be bothered (e.g. at the end of the fourth 'theme'), you can simply run past enemies and take negligible damage - less so than you would if you tried to fight it, especially seeing regen items are so rare.• And least importantly: this game is evidently unfinished. I understand it's a roguelike, but it does need a bit more content. If you could fetch the orb, run back to base, then go on another mission (assuming the orb unlocks a 'new' dungeon), that would be cool. Or challenges, modifiers, things to unlock, weapons to start with, etc., that would be awesome. I just feel like I couldn't play through it again. Maybe levelling up should unlock cool spells, or something similar? I don't feel like I need to grind or farm in the dungeon to look for some awesome and rare loot that makes me godlike. It needs something rare like that, or something that unlocks. In my opinion, that's how Risk of Rain is just infinitely replayable.TL/DR: I still would totally play it again, but it's relatively easy to finish in the first play-through. This game is already good, and I'm assuming it'll be great by the time it's out of Beta! :-)

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I requested refund right away.It's fun for the first little while, but it doesn't take long to figure out that this game lacks any real content.I decided to research this game (wiki) after playing for a while.Here's my conclusion.There's a lack of monster and level diversity, there isn't a huge variety of items, there's no way to sell items (not a huge issue, but still worth mentioning).The game engine was well made, the dungeons are somewhat fun to explore, but it's easy to see how this game would get repetitive fast. It's strikingly similar to Minecraft, yet different. While Minecraft focuses on exploration and diversity (biomes, items, creatures, etc.), the developers of this game only chose to focus on dungeon exploration with little creativity in respect to monsters, items, and biome.I understand content takes time to add, but this game is already in beta, lacks a solid update history, and most importantly - diversity in monster, characters, and items. Let's get real, this game has been out since 2013 and it is now 2016 - So where's the content?While this game may provide fun for a short while, I would stay away from this one until the developers can get their act together.Consumers work hard for their money and deserve a polished game - this one is just not there yet.

number of helpful: 28 of 31 people (90%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								A window in to the old school ways of dungeon crawling and FPS gameplay that's just as approachable for new and old gamers alike! Back when games didn't bog you down with forced tutorial segements where the game treats you like you have the IQ of a bee against a window, games presented you the tools and the world and said "you're on your own, good luck! You're gonna need it..." Through careful traversal of the world and observation of your enemies and the effects of your gear you became your own tutor. your victories and your failures were down to your strats, observations and reactions. This is what made games like Doom, Half Life and other 90's titles such classics and Delver brings back that style of gaming with grace and it's such a joy to see this approach to gaming still existant and appealing in this era of the industry!Delver is a dungeon crawler, first person roguelike where permadeath results in the loss of your character upon death along with your items and level. That SOUNDS punishing but with out it, the appeal of this game is simply lost and it takes the experience of being in this amazing game to really appreciate that. You do however keep any gold you find which allows you purchase items you feel may help either balance the weaknesses in your gameplay style or further boost your strengths. The game is split in to dungeon levels which go:Dungeon 1Dungeon 2Caves 1Caves 2Sewers 1Sewers 2RuinsThe objective is to make your way in to the cursed ruins and obtain an orb to then double back and actually climb your way through those levels back to the surface, all while being pursued by the undead that roam the ruins looking for their orb!Enemy types, difficulties and tactics vary through each level, constantly keeping you on your toes to see whether or not the enemy is fast, slow, hits hard or poisons or maybe they use projectile attacks. Eventually you'll come to recognise things like audio cues of monsters, the sounds of traps being detonated or particle effect remains on the floor, giving you clues as to what's gone on in the area.The game's golden feature which makes this such an appealing experience is that everything is useful and thinking outside the box is critical to success. And the beauty of it is it's all down to you which makes the gameplay so rewarding with even the simplest of feats. for example. I noticed my run speed was still too slow for me to run over a trap and not get enough distance to get away from the blast radius it triggers but I remembered seeing enemies also trigger traps so I thought "what about items?" I took a broken wand with no charges left in it and threw it on the trap. Sure enough it detonated and I could move through it during the down time while the trap was resetting. Not only did that feel rewarding that my plan worked but I now knew that 'useless' items like empty wands still served a purpose, so I kept on to one or two as I explored. Another example was when I was using a bow. I noticed sometimes when I missed, the arrow would bounce off a wall and I could pick it back up. When I came across the mage skeletons who are very projectile heavy and can easily be a problem, I wondered if I could bounce my arrows off the wall around a corner to fight them whilst being safe from their projectiles. I aimed at an angle and fired, sure enough the mage caught the arrow in his eye socket and he popped! Another rewarding feeling and a little more understanding of the game's mechanics!Delver is a very small budget game and when you get the hang of it, it can easily be done in under an hour which results in the game resetting after a victory screen as if you died which is a shame because it feels like all the content can be experienced in a short manner of time and I want to spend so many hours in the world of Delver! The game is still early access as I write this so here's hoping the amazing guy behind this high potential title keeps dishing out further quality content!(P.S. The projectile particle effects remind me so much of Heretic's visuals and that's just another 1000 bonus points to this title :P)

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I say it in the most manly way possible when I say this game is adorable.It will lure you in with its cute, nostaligic-yet-tasteful, sprite based enemies. It will drop plenty of sweet, varied loot for you, keeping you in the game and letting you become further and further immersed. And just when you say "This game is fun,  but a bit easy", it will brutally murder you and take all your stuff, leaving you only with coins and questions.Being entirely randomly generated, from the size of each floor to the quality of each weapon, there is exellent replay value.   Each floor has a mix of challenging enemies and total pushovers, keeping the experience fun throughout the playthrough as the difficulty slowly raises. That is, until a sudden surprise right near the end ;)For its price and file size, the game is a fantastic little timewaster that is very easy to pick up but very hard to put down. If you're concerned about the Early Access status, I bought this game when it first popped up on Steam and felt it was a complete experience then. And yet somehow every update seems to make it better and better. No regrets.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								A very interesting blend of dungeon crawl and roguelike, this game has held my attention since I first purchased it.  It's a good addition to your library.  It's simple enough to start playing when you have limited time or attention, but robust enough that you don't feel like you're playing an indie throwaway.  Its randomized levels provide replay value and the ability to stockpile gold between runs allows for you to splurge on a run to give yourself a head start.  Also, the developer is very active.  It's obvious Delver is a labor of love.Some tips, for new players:1. Your HP refills when you level up, so stockpile your food in early levels.2. If you inventory is getting full, leave a treasure trove of food and wands at the ladder down to the next floor.3. Heavier armor slows you down, but not as much as you might think.4. When leveling, I prioritize Health > Attack > Speed.  I've never put points into the stats that buff wands or archery.5. Zombies and caterpillars (but not spiders, as of when I wrote this) will poison you with their attacks.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								I'm enjoying the game immensely.  It's quite simple to pick up and understand, you can play it for 5 minutes or 5 hours and it's always fun.  If you end up dying (which will likely happen a lot for the first few tries) you restart at the camp and go through a new dungeon with randomized equipment to start but gold carries over from each life.  There are 2 shop characters in the camp outside, 1 for general equipment (armor, weapons, potions, etc) and the other for scrolls that might come in handy.  Generally use the wands when you have them and you'll last longer.  Anything ranged works best.Overall I'd give the game 9/10.  I only drop it by 1 cause it's a little repetitive over time but still quite fun even with the simple graphics which I find perfect for the game and it's style of play.  It's also not a super expensive game and as of the time I played it I didn't notice any bugs through about 6 levels of the dungeon.  Everything seems to function like it's suppose to and makes it a wonderful game.

content:
Posted: February 25
Early Access Review
								Delver is an early access roguelike game that has been in early access for way too long. While the soundtrack and retro graphics are cozy, other things such as frustrating ranged combat and the overall lack of stability are not. The random crashes are especially bad and the sound will occasionally cut out for no reason. After crashing to desktop for the third time in an hour, and having to log off each time because the lingering process prevents re-launching the game, I decided to put this title down for good. There’s no reason a game that started development in 2013 should still have so many stability issues in 2017. Buy something else.

Early Access Review
								So i felt this game needs a review because of how it good it is (in my opinion). I'll start off by saying that this is a game in which when you die you loose just about everything, i won't tell you what you keep because it defeats the purpose of playing it doesn't it. But this game combines a perfect sense of rogue-like/fps with modular enhancements on the website. The game although being in Early-Acess, which i can already hear the ugggh another one. Yes it is in early access but it being in early access means lots of updates and things to look forward to in the game to make you want to play it even more after each update.Pros- It combines rogue-like/rpg style game with a nice combat experience- Really simple and easy to pick up even just to play around 1 life- Animations are pretty decent for what it is- In my opinion its not to hard or too easy it hits that sweet spot that most games don't - Varying loot is always a thing i love to see and this game has it and like skyrim you want to pick up everything- Modular (-meaning skins, hopefully in the future other mods)- It has a random loadout everytime delving into the dungeon that keeps the game refreshing Things to Improve Upon- Just some mechanics nothing to important like the save game feature- I would like to see a bigger camp in the future maybe, just with a bit more options maybe a reward/trophy house of boss another idea - Steam achievements would be nice so I work towards or find something to it that adds a rewarding experienceCons- For an early access not sure it can be counted as a con but it falls short beatable in like 3 hours since i last played it :(- It's not really rewarding for the outside camp experience to meYes it's a good game but there arent many cons i found in my experience of playing it all the way through. I will always look forward to hack and slashing my way to the end again as the game updates. This will definately go on the list of games i follow to see what comes of it. its an easy 7.5/10 :3. Buy it, its like 8$ #worth

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I played this game for a solid three hours right after I got it and never once got bored. Sure, I almost rage quit a couple times, but that's just video games. I like that you dont customize your character because if you did you would be way more upset with dying (which you do QUITE A BIT). No two dungeons are the same, and you face new challenges and get new rewards with every delve into the myserious ruins. Some rooms are the same each play (just the rooms with transition ladders, however), yet the game never runs out of surprises or fun. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the dungeon crawler genre, pixelated graphics, or adventure games in general. P.S. : you can not jump in this game, space is just another attack key. I learned this the hard way, with the help of a gap, ledge, and pool of lava.

Early Access Review
								PROS:-Dive-on-in style of play, start the game, jump in and try your luck!-Permadeath makes the game feel more enthralling until the inevitable loss of a character you like/got far with.-Lovely pixelated art style.-Britty guud atmosphere, and the level designs are varied, too!-Combat feels good, and kills gitcha PUMPED.-Exploration is satifying.-Loot is restricted to items you can use, no shop/merchant goo-goo-goo bull♥♥♥♥♥♥-Randomly generated dungeons keep each play session fresher than the average bear.CONS:-Pretty much abandoned, although the devs beg to differ on their twitter (but I'm not making a twitter to find out lol ♥♥♥♥ twitter).-Few bugs here and there, nothing really game-breaking that I've run into thus far.-Is still in beta stage after being released nearly three years ago for EA (Early Access) purchase.-Last update was September 21st, 2015. Quickly approaching the year mark since it was updated.All in all, I'll gladly change this review to a recommendation as soon as another update comes along/the devs show they care/it comes out as a full release. Really fun FPS roguelike, but unless you can comfortably toss $7.99 away on a game that may or may not be finished, I'd recommend waiting for a sale or it's full release.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pretty decent game. It still needs work and I honestly think you should hold out for a release because it's been four months since the last word on development and honestly this game is barely worth $8 in it's current state. It's a pretty engaging game if dungeon crawls are your thing. It's got all the stuff that makes a dungeon crawler wonderful. I enjoyed it a lot but I have a couple gripes:First, this game is like all the other roguelike-likes. It has randomly generated levels and some light RPG mechanics and that's it for likenesses. I would love to have a roguelike-like that doesn't distance itself so heavily from roguelike mechanics, but what can you do.Second, the difficulty spikes through the ceiling at the end. The game's really easy for something that bills itself as a roguelike game, up until the very end. It's really frustrating to work your way through the game for an hour or two only to hit an unbeatable ending that throws the cheapest difficulty it can at you: flooding the rooms with spawns of endgame enemies at a rate of ~1/sec(that's an honest estimation, not an exaggeration). I'm all for reasonable progression of difficulty, and this ain't it.Overall, I kinda-sorta recommend this game. It definitely needs work, but I think you'll find some enjoyment out of it in its current state. Whether that enjoyment is worth $8 is debatable. I would personally suggest you wait for more work to be done on it before buying.

number of helpful: 95 of 158 people (60%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
Early Access Review
								Delver looked good. I heard a good review and it was on sale so I checked it out. I beat the game in 74 minutes. After learning some basic strategies, enemies became super predictable and completely unthreatening. At no point was there any fear or tension. I killed the boss without even realizing his significance. With no enemy scaling, leveling health and decking myself out in good armor made me essentially unkillable. Even barring that, the endgame whoopsie do of having to run back through the entire level refilled with monsters was a cakewalk. You could run circles around them and not get hit. On top of that, the twist ending bored me. There was no presentation to it, no aplomb, no reason to care about it. I have no reason to come back to this game. I have seemingly seen all there is to see in it. I enjoyed my time delving, but have been given no reason to ever come back to it. There is no point to this game being a roguelike, which was the entire reason I wanted to play it in the first place. Even if there is some second and third layer of fun I could come back to, it's not evident. Character progression is not saved. There is no reward for beating the game.I had fun. I was expecting so much more. The money per time enjoyed ratio is higher than a longer theatrical release. That's not what I've come to expect out of games.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is one of those games that don't look as fun as the playthroughs of it. I was in love with the graphics, but the charm soon wears off, within only three hours for me personally. Regaurdless, don't be completely deterred from this game by my review. You can still get some enjoyment out of it (though I would never recommend it at full price). Don't have high expectations though. After watching several playthroughs of the game and seen what I thought was a ton of fun, I was disappointed with the actual product.I've seen this being described as a "a rougebased 3d RPG game with permadeath" To put it more basic, it's a dungeon crawler at it's simplist. There's nothing complex about it. Explore the dungeon fighting enemies, leveling up, and picking up loot like weapons, food, potions, and armor. So anyone can jump into it right away. However it's not exactly easy either. In the beginning I struggled with not succumbing to foes as it's an art to get close enough to hit an enemy with your beginning weapon (a very short dagger) without getting attacked yourself every time. You have to be at just the right distance to hit them without getting hit back, and since you only start with a mere 8 HP, it can be tough for new players, but it's just something to get used to. The goal of the game is to descend down 7 floors, defeat a boss, collect an orb from him, and to work your way back up the 7 floors to leave without dying. Some people have said the game is very easy, and that they were able to beat it in a mere hour or less. I've had a hard time with it, and I'll explain why. It's typical logic that you need to be a high level the farther you advance. Althoguh other players may disagree about this with me, I've found that I've needed to grind, or else I'm just not leveled up enough the deeper into the dungeon I get. The big problem with this is that it's almost impossible to grind in Delver. After you clear the floor the first time, enemies will continue to spawn a little (for a short time), but they'll spawn less and less until they stop all together. When I backtrack, I only run into a few to zero enemies, which means I have to go back and forth on a floor over and over again to try to level up. It's a very slow process. I also have to cover the two glitches I noticed. The first thing I noticed was how very laggy such a graphically simple game was, and then I noticed more specifically, it was lagging in time with the music. I had to turn the music off because it really slowed down the game. Maybe it's just my laptop and won't happen to all computers, but I figured I would give the heads up to people. The sound effects worked just fine however, and I want to mention the nice touch it added to the gameplay. The enemies would say phrases like "I heard something" and "What was that?" that would make you aware of their presence. Now you could still be spooked by an enemy, because some enemies wouldn't make much noise, but it did cut back on the startling surprise. The second glitch only happens in the caves, which are the 3rd and 4th levels in the game. The cave walls are very uneven and blocky, over all very odd looking. It's not easily clear where you can fit through and where you can't. Quite a few times, I got a little too close to just the side of the wall when I was walking, and I immediately got stuck. I refused to start over, and so I would spend 10-15 minutes trying to get myself free. For anyone else who experiances this, first take off your helmet, and then repeatedly use a weapon (I found the dagger most helpful) to hit either above or below you while holding in the key to go backwards. It's very tedious and annoying, and there are no changes to show your progress, but all at once you'll be free. The very last time however, I got stuck for good and tried for probably a half hour to get out to no avail. There's nothing more frusterating then losing precious progress. There are three other minor things worth mentioning. You collect gold, but you can't buy anything during that playthrough. Instead, the gold carries over when you die, and you can buy items the next round, before you enter the dungeon again. The way you leveled up bugged me. There are six different attributes, but when you level up, only three available ones show up, randomized each time. If you want to upgrade a certain skill, it often isn't there to choose. There are also different kinds of pressure plates in the game. Some hurt you, but one kind is a teleportation pad that will teleport you to a random place in the level. In all my time of playing, I have not once come across a single teleporter. I wondered if they had removed it in an update, but there are places in the level that you can not physically reach yourself.You'll see in other reviews that this game doesn't have a lot of replayability. I didn't believe this at first, but it rings true. You'd think a game with randomly generated dungeons would have endless fun, but it actually gets old fast. I can't put my finger on as to why, but it does. Perhaps it's *too* simple, and needs something more to spice it up. It's still in it's beta state (at the time of writing this review) so I won't knock it off yet. It still has time to grow and evolve. I personally did not enjoy it a lot, but I feel like other players will get more, longer lasting fun out of it than I did because I'm very picky about dungeon crawlers. They are definately not my favorite genre, so that may have contributed to why I didn't enjoy this game more. For the record, this game isn't horrible or even bad. I just thought it was okay, and that's the only reason I'm not recommending it, but that's just my own opinion. It is surely possible to enjoy this game, so give it a try if you've had your eye on it. Useful guides: 


The Delver basic guide 
A Guide for Delver
By: Ethan

			A guide to playing, modding, & winning Delver.		





Getting Started 
A Guide for Delver
By: Renoco

			I highly suggest you play a few times without reading any of this. Nothing better then jumping into a game clueless, it's fun to discover.		


  for the basic tips and inventory section


Glen Chico's Guide to (Almost) Always Winning 
A Guide for Delver
By: Glen Chico

			My guide to how I beat Delver and how you can too!		


  a more specfic, common strategy

number of helpful: 18 of 25 people (72%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								English version (Wersja polska poniżej)This charming little piece of dungeon crawling may have nothing truely unique to offer, but besides that, it's simple,solid and stylish. And it provides that eerie feeling I remember from exploring the caves in the Minecraft.  The combat is simple, yet engaging. There is a variety of melee,  ranged and magical weapons available and balancing quick, strong and ranged attacks is the key to survival. The graphics of this game are really appealing. While pixelated, they perfectly fit together to create a consistent "minecrawl" experience. Special mention goes to the utterly hilarious, 80-90s anime styled facial expressions the human enemies make when hit. Music is also likable and moody. What I didn’t really enjoy is the character leveling system.  While it is traditionally experience based, on every level the player is given 3 choices on what to upgrade. The problem is that there are more than three stats and thus sometimes there is no option to improve the desired characteristic and the  progress gets a bit random. Furthermore, there is no description regarding what a particular stat does. While most of them are self-explanatory,  a seasoned RPG gamer in me desires at least a basic defining of the difference between the Speed and Agility. Not much of a problem though – characters don’t usually live long enough to regret.  On the other hand, the game goes to the great lengths to make itself as user-friendly as the dungeon crawler can be. Traps are always clearly visible, and one cannot die of hunger, food restores the hit points instead.The greatest problem with this game, at least for me, is the fact that it gets boring after a few runs. Nonetheless, it is perfect for the short evening sessions. Furthermore, when I decide to play a rogue it means something, since I’m usually too tired of starting over again and again in the real life to follow the same pattern in games. Still, Delver seems to be the right choice to spend a few nights with sword in your main and a glass of whisky in off hand. Yeah, I too used to play an ambidextrous character in the good, old DnD days. Wersja polska Delver jest uroczym, małym dungeon crawlerem. Nie wprowadza do gatunku nic nowego, ale za to jest prosty, solidny i stylowy. I powoduje to samo osobliwe uczucie co długi spacer po jaskiniach w Minecrafcie.System walki jest prosty, ale wciągający. Gra daje do użytku spory wybór broni białej, dystansowej oraz zaklęć i znalezienie między nimi balansu jest kluczem do przetrwania. Grafika, mimo pikseli na pół ekranu, robi świetne wrażenie. Kolory są jaskrawe i dobrane tak, że idealnie pasują do tego „minecrawla”. Gra dostaje ode mnie dodatkowe punkty za miny które robią niektórzy przeciwnicy kiedy oberwą – przypominające anime z lat 80-90, potrafią naprawdę rozbawić.  Muzyka też od razu wpada w ucho i świetnie buduje nastrój. Gra podpada za to sysyemem levelowania postaci. Tradycyjnie, opiera się on na expach zdobywanych na wrogu, a przy każdym levelu dostajemy do wyboru 3 staty które możemy „podbić”. Problem polega na tym że cech opisujących postać jest więcej, więc czasem nie dostajemy opcji ulepszenie tego co akurat by się przydało i sprawia że rozwój postaci przebiega nieco losowo. Dodatkowo, cechy nie są w żaden sposób opisane. Niby nie problem domyślić się od czego jest atak a od czego wytrzymałość, ale zatwardziały RPGowiec we mnie domaga się jednak wytłumaczenia różnicy między szybkością a zręcznością. Inna sprawa że nie jest to jakiś straszny problem – bohater i tak na ogół nie żyje na tyle długo żeby żałować dokonanych wyborów. Z drugiej strony Delver stara się jak może, by być przyjaznym graczowi. Pułapki zawsze są widoczne z daleka, a jedzenie odnawia HPki – nie można tu umrzeć z głodu.   Największy problem, przynajmniej dla mnie, to fakt że gra nudzi się dość szybko. Na krótkie sesje jest jednak idealna.  Co więcej, jeżeli polecam jakiegoś rogulca, musi coś w tym być, na ogół brakuje mi cierpliwości by zaczynać grę od początku po tym jak zginę. Podsumowując: Delver nadaje się idealnie do spędzenia kilku nocy z mieczem w jednej, a szklaneczką whisky w drugiej ręce. A co? Też grałem „oburęcznymi” postaciami w starych, dobrych, DnDkowych czasach.

								This is a very promising game judging on what I've just played. I started playing two hours ago and I haven't stopped. I even got my sister to play it. Early Access Review
								A very neat little game, and a very great roguelike for people who like those. Its combat and item systems are pretty well made and the difficulty progresses fairly as you progress. Since this game is in early access, there are obviously going to be new things added soon most likely, and the game is made in a way where it is very open to new things, which is what I really enjoy about it. Even though death means you start all over, you don't have to always start completely from scratch, as you keep your collected gold and can buy powerful items from the start if you wish to do so, which is another thing real enjoyable about this game. Overall, my early access rating would have to be 9/10. If you really enjoy roguelike games, this game is an amazing approach to it, and any fans of the genre would definitly enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I beat this game on my very first try in under two hours, and I've just realized that that means I can get a refund for it, which I'm now sure to do. For what this game is, it looks and feels very, very nice. The pixel art, engine, and polish on this game are all very well done, and the beginning of the game left a pretty good taste in my mouth (which may be more than some people say for my game, Barony). However, this game simply has no depth to it. The music is very limited and loops constantly, so even though it sounds nice at first it gets tiring quickly. There are no skill trees, there is no diversity in each playthrough, and the mechanical variety of the game is just so low -- it's hard to describe, but gameplay-wise, there's no MEAT to this game.I was not aware that this game even existed when I made my own first-person "roguelike", and I've only just now played it, so I fully admit I may be biased -- but after having beaten this game, as well as coming away from it from an initially positive impression, I have to say I am not too impressed with this game now. The developers are very smart and talented, but I just don't think they put in enough effort with this game. This is probably what I'd call a wasted opportunity for some really nice first-person RPG goodness.

content:

Early Access Review
								Delver is an addicting, first-person, dungeon crawler with procedurally generated dungeons. It is still of course unfinished, so there are bugs to fixed and new things to be added, but it is still very satisfying. However, it doesn't really bring much new to the table. It's still a beautiful game in both sound, graphics, and gameplay, but it's not quite a masterpiece. It's like one of Picasso's early paintings. It's still great, but not like his later paintings which truly defined him. Nonetheless, it is still tons of fun to play, and keeps on bringing you back again and again, even after you've beaten the game. Despite not being completely inventive, it still is a lovely game, and even for $7.99, considering that it is still is in early access, i highly reccomend it.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok, so let me be perfectly blunt here. I have played little more than an hour of this game so far, but I can already sum up everything I have to say about Delver in one word: Potential.Delver is a fresh, unique take on the rogue-like games that have been pouring in recently from many indie developers from all over the world. It takes on many thematic rogue-like elements: It's challenging, randomly generated, and as fun as a bag full of rabid chipmunks dumped into an elementary school.I'm not saying this game is without its issues, but it's still in its early access phase, and must be taken with a grain of salt. Considering this fact, Delver is chocked full of endless potential. Its first-person perspective and highly pixelated environment and graphics allow this game far more room to breathe then one would expect at first glance. Even in its early phases, the amount of different consumable items and pieces of unique equipment are quite impressive, and the level-up system that resets after every miserable failure allows a very immersive RPG-like quality to the game. You're able to play differently every single run. Want to focus on high armor and melee combat? Go right ahead! Feel like going for a more mobile, long-range bow combatant? Be my guest! Or maybe you just want to pump all of your points into magic and blow the CRAP out of every enemy in sight with one of the many different elemental weapons in the game. Why wouldn't you?!It is this amount of flexibility within a game that is comprised of so little options as of right now that makes me positive that there's no where to go but up from here for Delver. So many environments yet to be created; so many monsters yet rendered in that simplistic-yet-beautiful art style; many more items, potions, and pieces of armor yet to be looted off of bandit corpses or found in the dank corner of a cave! Heck, there is even a large part of the Delver community that claims this game has everything it needs to move on to an online co-op mode! Who knows?All I can say is, that even after only an hour of gameplay, I can already close my eyes and imagine what can be done with a game this inventive, this creative, this simple, and this ambitious! If you haven't taken a peek at Delver yet, I suggest very highly, for the love of yourself AND your rabies-free elementary schoolers that you do. This game is nothing but raw potential and ingenuity, and I KNOW you don't want to miss out on it! That being said:This is the Captain, Signing Out.

								Your crave for adventure starts here! Bleed out of your eyes as you fight through poison zombies, magic skeletons, crazy ladies which are impossible to avoid, and bats.. SO MANY BATS!!! Besides all the rage that will consume your soul as you delve deeper and deeper to the Earth's god damn core, you will have the time of your life! I give this game a 9/10, and here is it's draw backs:-The boss fight wasn't as intense or memorable as I would have liked it to be-There wasn't much of an ending after the boss fight (Although I kind of expected that)

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Picked up Delver during the Steam Sale. Definitely worth the $3 it cost.I wouldn't call it '3d' in more than a limited sense, it feels a lot more like Doom's 2.5d- 3d environments, sprite monsters, etc. Still, it's one save file you can't back up and one life in a randomly generated roguelike. It actually makes for a pretty cool story:I started off in a little camp with a couple of shopkeepers and the obligatory guest appearance of Old Man Exposition, who explained that there was a MacGuffin at the bottom of yonder dungeon. He also seemed troubled that people kept going in but never coming out. More on that later.So I notice I have no gold, yet everything the shopkeepers sell costs gold. Okay, fine, we'll come sell some crap later. I head down the ramp, at which point the music changes to a far darker and more foreboding track. It was more apt than I realized, but I ignored it as I clicked on the door.Ten minutes later and I'm about halfway through the first floor of the dungeon, packing my inventory with goodies to sell. You get a pretty generous inventory, and I was crammed to the gills with extra armor and weapons to unload. A quick glance at my map and I headed for the exit. Reached the door... and it's locked. The key is the MacGuffin. ♥♥♥♥.I do a quick Google search and lo and behold, there is no selling of items to shops- any gear other than the best stuff you've got is essentially dead weight. I tossed half my inventory on the spot and continued downwards, making it three levels before getting vaporized in a headlong hasted charge on a Beholder. Thus ended Game One.A couple presses of the Return key later and I find myself back in the camp. My inventory looks a little different- a different starting wand, a gold potion instead of a red one (the potions randomize their effects every game and you have to find out which is which by drinking them- and one just happens to be poison; the game really does hate you). And now I find out why there's shopkeepers: My gold carries over between runs, so previous me can give current me a head start with some gear and a stat point or two. As I got ready and drank my starter potion to find out what it was (arcane shield this time), I remembered the old man's words:"There's a lot of people going in, but nobody ever comes out."Over the next two hours I went in several times, and never came back out. Death happens a lot in this game- and usually right when you start to get cocky. I began learning to glance at my health bar every few seconds, more if I was in combat. Keeping myself in top shape was a priority- every level had its own special combination of ranged and melee mobs, and more often than not you'd find yourself beset by something with a sword that you'd have to kill while dodging fire from other things trying to vaporize you. Corners became my best friend- either because I'd lead the melee mob around them and out of the ranged mob's line of fire, or just as a place to sit down and cry now and then.Since it actually has a win condition, I can say I felt my pulse quicken and nerves get twitchier as I got towards the end. I'll try not to spoil much, but the game doesn't really get hard until AFTER you get the MacGuffin: now you have to get out. Oh, and did I mention that picking up the MacGuffin awakens the undead horde that's apparently buried under every square foot of this dungeon?For the last fifteen minutes I was continually mumbling "oh♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; under my breath as I dodged through the dungeon towards the exit with the MacGuffin, hoping I'd invested enough speed while leveling up to outpace the horde of undead nipping at my heels (I hadn't, one type of undead in particular is fast, flies, and will bite your face off if ignored). Having to turn to kill the speedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I almost instantly found myself swallowed by the undead wave advancing behind me, forcing me to burn my two most powerful wands to blow a hole in their ranks and escape. It's at this step that preparation becomes critical: I'd carefully and methodically laid a cache of gear for myself at the lower entrance to every floor; a wand, a health item, and some protective potions awaited me in the short breath I had while the skeletons closed in from the darker parts of the level. Dumped the empty wands, got some regeneration going, and off it was again to try and make it through Skeletor's Funhouse without joining the ranks of my would-be murderers.By the time I got up the first floor again I was feeling good- I had a feeling that I'd be pretty worn down by this point, so I'd left an exceptionally generous cache on this floor. With no reason to hold back, I lined up every wand I had left and burned a path to the exit. Even then, so many mobs were in my way that I used up every wand and was still just outside the final room leading to the exit. The only mob in the way is one of the first-floor goons that happened to spawn, but my arrows were used up on the way down and my wands on the way up, leaving me with my trusty but oh-so-weak shortsword. I'd decided that I'd finesse my melee combat this playthrough, and as such had put all of my stat points into speed, magic, and health- I relied on careful maneuvering to win melee, a tactic you can afford on the way down.This was not the way down. This was the way up, and I had enough undead closing in on me to make Left 4 Dead blush. I have 60+ hp and am regenerating, but while I brutally stab the mob in front of me to death my health bar is getting gnawed to nothing. I was in the single digits when my victim finally keeled over and died, leaving me to burst unopposed through the chokepoint, leave my undead pursuers behind, and have the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic door-opening ever as I got to the exit, barely alive but victorious.So yeah, it's a fun game. Give it a whirl.

Early Access Review
								As much as I wanted to like it, there is a severe lack in content in Delver. The game can be somewhat fun, but once you realize that you've seen about everything in the first hour or two, it loses its appeal. And unlike other dungeon crawlers, there is practically no replay value due to a lack of variety. Also, as often mentioned by others, with a slow pace in updates, it doesn't seem that this game will reach a state that reverses this opinion for me any time soon or possibly ever. For $8, it isn't awful, and there are glimmers of a good game underneath. But the game itself is too barebones; you may as well throw in a few more dollars and find a better rogue lite for your money's worth.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								In response to the recent crap about this game being abandoned:Now I have been hearing a lot of crap about how this game has been abandoned and how you “Should not buy it until its finished.” Screw those guys. They have NOT played it enough. I mean the guys have not even played 5 hours. So yes this game has not been updated since 9/20/2015, but if you take a honest look at what they have here its a near complete game. The only update it may need are a couple of bug fixes to things not even game breaking. I mean its not like cube world where there is nothing and might be abandoned. Cube world is boring and abandoned. This game is fun and might be abandoned. This game still has new things to throw at me and I have played 42 hours so far and thinking I've seen everything but then I made a new play through and boom I've seen a dungeon layout that I've never seen before. I even saw some treasure rooms and I'm like “Since when did delver have treasure rooms?” Put this game on your wish list and buy it when its on sale. This game is worth it.Now time to my actual reviewThis game is a throwback to how games used to be. Before story was added. Before you needed to know enough statistics you might as well get a fricken degree in the stuff. I thinking of YOU pokemon, I love you but my gosh your competitive play is just full of maths. Literally you wake up at a camp and need talk to some guys and walk into a door and boom your in the game. Your goal? Get to the end of the dungeon, grab the orb and get back to the start. Sounds easy right? Hah! Nope! As soon as you grab the orb, the quiet peacefull dungeon run you had on the way down, which I must say isn't very hard but just engaging enough to keep playing but at the same time punishes your mistakes, is now a absolute hell hole where you just want to survive the trek up. I make sounds of terror that I have never made before on my way up. If your an angry person, this game may not be for you just for this part. My gosh I love it. As soon as you grab the orb you see why this game is called rouge like.I rate this game 10/10 yes I really do, I don't care if its abandoned or not this is a good game.If you don't want to buy it now put it on your wish list and remember it exists because you have no excuse to not buy this game when its on sale. This is one of the best Indie games I've played and deserves more credit.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
Early Access Review
 A Recipe for Nostaglic and Indie Goodness Mix "The Legend of Zelda" with "Shadowgate" together and sift "Dragon Warrior" through the top and fold it over in a large mixing bowl of condensed "Doom". Put the contents in a pan buttered with "Dungeons of Dagorath" and into the oven pre-heated at 16-bit graphics and what do you know? You get THIS delicous nostalgic and exciting gem called "Delver".I just LOVE retro games, even though I didn't exist in the 80's or even the 90's. And you don't see tweens who would rather play Centipede than Call of Duty enough these days. (Maybe only where I live.) Anyways, the simplistic fun of those games just tugs at my heartstring. Everything from Coleco-vision to the Nintendo 64 I love. (And I don't think E.T. for the Atari 2600 is that bad either.) Well, I shouldn't say EVERY GAME or EVERY SYSTEM. (shudders at the thought of the Philips CD-i) But, I bet you get the picture. I was looking in the Google Play store on my tablet, searching "What other users installed" for Minecraft Pocket Edition. I scrolled WAY down until my eyes caught the glimpse of a simple 8-bit figure wearing a green shirt and holding a stick. I decided to check it out. Now what I DON'T like is a classic game ripoff. But I can't find a game in the back of my head that is almost exactly the same as the game Delver. So, I decided to buy it, hoping my money didn't go to waste. The description of the game is definatly true to its word, and I enjoyed it. Sure, there were a couple bugs in the game, and the controls were kind of awkward, I really love the graphics, the concept and, overall, the entire game. A while after that, I got Steam. When I discovered Delver was also on Steam, I couldn't be more excited. The controls were MUCH better than the version I had on my tablet. I just couldn't wait for the next updates. Well, that's my story how I found Delver, but then, there are also reasons I LOVE to play Delver.I've read some of the negative reviews on Steam, some of them complain that there is little story to this game. I could care less about a story than those guys. I would rather just play the game and explore a dangerous dungeon in which I would probably die a horrible death in order to get a useless item because "what the heck," than sit through endless cutscenes or do a lot of reading. The leveling up system is both very simplistic, but very effective and game-changing at the same time. The music is AWESOME! I could listen to the game's tracks all day. Getting to the Orb, the music is somewhat calm but suspensful and adventurous at the same time. When you go back to the surface, though, the music immediatly switches to all out frightening and suspensful, raising your stress meter. The abundant variety of weapons, armor, wands and the ability to hold something on your left hand is remarkable and you can't help but to be very stingy about the items you have in your inventory. You never know what the potions would do in each game, and which ones to drink or not. But as long as you know which potion is which in the earliest floors, The relevently small inventory space show that there is not a lot to spare and you need to be very conservative, in which I like. The easier reach to the Orb will make you feel that this game is to easy and you become cocky. But once you get the Orb, you realize that Delver's adventure is not yet over. You still need to escape to the surface. That's when all heck breaks lose. Enemies start to respawn, not to metion those annoying skeleton mages whose magic cooldown seems like a half a second. The difficulty gets much harder than ever before, and you have a very long way to go before you get to the top. The entire thrill and the adventure of the game captures my heart.There are not many things for me to wish anymore about this game. Although, a few things doesn't mean anything at all, despite how amazing I believe this game is. Every once in a blue moon, the rest of the dungeon becomes impossible to progress and continue, which is very dissapointing the moment you discover it. On your journey to the Yithidian Orb, I noticed that enemies don't respawn. I would like the developers to add respawning to the first half of the game to make it a little harder, but not too hard though. When you get to the boss, I would like the boss fight to be nessecary to get the Orb. Plus, the boss fight is insignificant and easy. All you need wolf down an arcane and iron skin potion and you practically won the fight. I've also noticed a pattern that some of the rooms are exactly the same in other runs, and that more variety of rooms and maps should be added. Bigger and more floors would be nice, too. Other than that, I have no other complaints.I can't wait when Delver is going to be off Beta stage. I hope more people will come and play this wonderful game. Delver team, don't stop on improving the game. Please know that this game has HUGE potential and that there are fans, eager to play the game.Well, that's all I have to say. Aldisimoo, OUT!

Early Access Review
 Early Access Review I'll start off by saying that this game has a lot of replay value, however it's a little on the short side and finishing the game isn't all that hard. One thing that I need to point out is just how beautiful this game is. The shape of the land isn't made of cubes like what you'll find in Minecraft, but it's all shaped to really make a dungeon, cave, or sewer scene come to life. The only thing that is cubey are the textures on the landscape.The combat is simple but it isn't boring. You can choose to use a dagger, sword, longsword, club, bow, or one of the many magic wands that do different things. Like a true RPG, as you play you'll level up, you can power up stats (health, speed, etc..), and you will also find higher level armor, weapons, and enemies.This is the perfect game for anyone looking for a rogue-like RPG dungeon crawler.Delver is worth the CDN$8.79 price. It has earned all of it's positive reviews.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Besides the typical trends of -INDIE- -ROGUELIKE- -PIXEL GRAPHICS- that games these days try and cash in on, this game is actually pretty fun. It felt reminiscent of Daggerfall's dungeons or early dungeon crawling games of the 90s except with modern controls and pacing. This isn't a turn based roguelike, which is hilarious refreshing in what is one of my favourite genres now bloated with similar games trying to cater to people who only care about what I said above  (memes indie 16-bit roguelikevmetrovai- blah blah blah etc etc).The aesthetics are crisp and colorful and some weapons feel weighty and it's very satisfying knocking out monsters or pesky mages into blood pudding. Also traps in the dungeons effect the bad dudes and I spent more than I'd like to admit trailing bandits into a spike pit. When you slap people's nuts a little too hard but not enough to put them down, they'll run off and try and flank/sneak up on you, which is cool.I put all my stats into defence and attack and wore big platemail armor. This worked pretty well until a bunch of spooky liches tore me a new one with magic while I was huffed and puffed trying to get away. Only downer is it's an early access game and could use some content or fleshing out. I made it down 7th or so floor before being lich target practice (apparently this is the last floor?). This game is under 10$ CDN, how can you say NO to this.I also smashed a bandit with a sword in the face with a hammer and it made a sound like he pooped himself while he flew off a cliff into lava from the blow.I give it 6 green potions out of cheese piece. YUM.

content:
Posted: March 24
Early Access Review
								Puzzled how this game is still Early Access.Delver is pretty decent. I'm not floored by much of anything but it's managed to keep my attention for more than 10 minutes, and with all the un-played games in my library that's a compliment. Visually it's fine to look at, the art style is a mix of 3D environments that have a definite Minecraft vibe, whereas enemies and items are 2D sprites - although the animation on them is well done and actually useful in predicting attacks to get timing down. The soundtrack is great although turning off the music can be useful as almost every enemy gives away it's position with some basic sounds. Combat is alright, although it feels a little sluggish - even when you're wielding something light and quick like a dagger. Magic is much more satisfying and useful, but there's not a lot of it. The same can be said of bows and arrows. I think the game would be a lot more enjoyable and replayable if both magic and archery were viable "builds" on their own and not just supplements to melee.Nothing too fancy here, I would recommend this only if you were really looking for something in this style of game.

content:
Posted: January 23
Early Access Review
								7/10A quite fun roguelike dungeon crawler, even though it has a very high frustration level involved.The premise is simple: you start a game, go in the dungeon, fight monsters, avoid traps, level up, find items and gear, then use what you have to get to the end of the dungeon, grab the orb and come back. Dungeons are randomly generated each time you go into a new level and even the potion effects are random each time you start a new game. It's simple enough, but not as easy to actually beat - could be perhaps described as "easy to play, hard to master", as you have to learn what stats work better for your play style, learn more about enemy behavior, wands and plan ahead to beat the game.As fun as the game is, there is a huge frustration level involved, not just because it's a roguelike game but also because of how the game works. The first reason is that the only thing carried over when you die is your money, which you can use to buy some starting gear, though that doesn't help much since gear will degrade with usage (specially weapons). The best thing you can buy is a potion that gives you an instant stat point to spend, but obviously it only lasts for one playthrough. The second reason is that sometimes the game can overwhelm you all of a sudden - maybe you're having a perfect playthrough, finding lots of good items and dealing with enemies one by one, then all of a sudden you find yourself in a situation where your health bar drops so quickly, you don't even notice it until you're dead. These sudden difficulty spikes make the game extremely frustrating at times.The game is currently on early access, so perhaps this issue will be addressed in the future, which might make the game a lot better than it currently is. Nonetheless, it's a fun and well made roguelike game.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								It looked great when I saw it on sale, so I picked Delver up. There are definitely a lot of good things going on with this game, and it has the potential to scale into something truly massive and amazing over time. I haven't tried the custom mod tools yet, though I'm hoping they provide options to greatly increase the depth of content available.After finally playing through it in its current state, I feel like I missed something - or the game is missing something - because it took me all of 1.6 hours to learn the game and complete it (even the run back) and the lack of a meaningful ending left it feeling like a hollow victory. I'd really love to talk with the developer and community together sometime to explore the current state of the game, and determine ways in which Delver could be made more amazing and worthwhile for everyone to buy and play. I was hoping for something that scales more like Diablo, 20+ floors and constantly rotating out gear for better stuff throughout the game, multiple classes with variations, well-defined boss enemies, or just to have truly everything randomized and have every experience be a new adventure. Right now the potions and dungeon layout are the only things which change, the variety of loot is rather static, and I come in exactly the same every time.

								I figured I'd say my piece.I love this game, I haven't played that long, but whenever I can't think of absolutely anything to do I always somehow end up playing this game. It's nice to see a Rogue Like that has a little bit of skill to it as well as the random aspect, although RNG can still sometimes kill you.I've never made it past the area after the sewers, crypt maybe? I can't remember what it's called. So I don't know how much end game content there is to this game. As it stands right now, it feels a little short, and a little shallow, but also not bad or unsatisfying. If this looks like a game that would appeal to you, it probably will.I give it a solid 7.5 out of 10.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								EDIT: I decided to come back to this to see what changes have been made, and guess what? Despite some changes that were for the better, the game still hasn't managed to get better in terms of gameplay. The game still feels like a bare bones action dungeon crawler RPG with rogue-like elements thrown in. Though it is very nice that you now have more use for your weapons than just killing enemies (for example, breaking down a door with your mace or breaking a crate in order to search for loot), that skill jars now cost more and that there is more variation with the music, the game still has not advanced enough for me to say that the game is going somewhere. In fact, I think the game actually took some steps back, especially with its new leveling system. The new leveling system works like this: each time you level up, you are allowed to put one point into one of three randomly chosen stats. This is a problem because it doesn't give the player a choice on what kind of build they actually want to have, which defeats the purpose of being able to put stat points into whichever stats you want in the first place. Now, once again, one might bring up the skill jars, but I should not have to grind money, die a couple of times, and then buy all these jars just to get the build I want to have, especially in a dull game like this. Speaking of dull, the game is still a dull hack and slasher RPG with enemies who are not very competent at catching up with you. Combat is still virtually the same, scroll wheels are still not an option, the game still lacks custimization features, etc. All in all, the game may have added some neat things, but it isn't enough to save the game. I would still not recommend picking this game up, at least for now, that is.ORIGINAL POST: Now that the October Patch is out and now that I've played some more of it, I will give my current thoughts on Delver. The good news is that the developer has revamped the RPG system. The bad news is that I still don't see it being a good game any time soon. My reasons? Lets start with the gameplay. The gameplay of Delver may have been expanded upon when it comes to the RPG system, but the gameplay still pretty much sucks♥♥♥♥♥ This time, the game has a shop and gold, and it saves your gold count when you die so that you can use that gold at the shop before entering the dungeon, which sounds nice, but can be used to break the game. How? By saving a ♥♥♥♥ ton of money (lets say about a little over a thousand gold) through multiple playthroughs and using that money to buy jars of skill, a type of item that sells for 20 gold and levels you up upon use, you can easilly kill the difficulty. Some may argue to not use them, seeing as they are optional, but they are in the game, and I feel that they shouldn't be that easy to get, seeing as this game is supossed to be a difficult action rogue-like RPG. In terms of combat, I think it's actually clunkier than the last time I played it, especially when it comes to the hit detection. There were moments in the game where I was hitting enemies, but the hit didn't register for any good particular reason. This was especially common with magic attacks. Speaking of magic, for some reasons, magic weapons seem to be quite overpowered, killing a lot of enemies in one hit. The game also has moments of being unbalanced, as I've had moments on the first floor where I got killed in one hit. The developer still hasn't added the ability to use the scroll wheel, which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, considering how many other First-Person RPGs make use of the scroll wheel to change weapons and items. The game also still likes to spawn very powerful equipment in early stages, though not as often as it did when I last played it, so that's a plus. In the end, however, the bad still outweighs the good, and Delver still feels like a generic Action-RPG with nothing going for it.Presentation wise, the game has made drastic changes with its visuals, and although I'm not too fond of these new visuals, they are ♥♥♥♥ tons better than the graphics that Delver used to have (seriously, those graphics were an eye sore). Music wise, Delver still has that god awful dungeon music, although the update added a new tune that is more pleasant to the ears to fit the shop camp that is outside the dungeon. An improvement in these areas, but they could still be better.And now, the performance. I don't know about anyone elses experience, but I found that the game is glitchier then when I last played it. Yeah, not a good thing at all. I had one moment in the game where I found a bow that was floating midair, and I couldn't take it for some reason. I even have the image to prove it. The game also loves to close on its own, as the game closed on me while I was in the dungeon. Also, the game is still unoptimized as ♥♥♥♥. Despite its improvements, the game is still rather ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and I still think that people should avoid this game at this point in time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12
Early Access Review
								I really like the optics, the athmosphere and the basic gameplay of Delver.It has four main problems:1: Arrows stack. Well, that is some do some don't. Arrows you buy at a marchant can only stack up to two arrows wich is not very helpfull at all. Some other arrows do stack though and sometimes it looks like arrows you pickd up again (a feature i really like) stack with arrows they haven't stacked with before. No idea what is going on there but it isn't very helpfull.2: Collision Detection for Arrows is terribble. That means that on several of enemys hitting the Sprite doesn't actually hit the enemy. On other enemys it's a game of luck if the arrow damages the enemy upon contact or just flys trough. This is seriously frustrat5ing especially when you want to concentrate on playing with bows and because you need to use all reserves avaiable to you to get trough the game. This leads to problem two.3: This game sooner or later is a game of attrition. Sooner or later you are going to die simply because the ressources like food and or potions aren't nearly enough to get you trough. Especially potions are superrare and you need at least one to even find out what they do because the potions change functions between attempts to master the dungeon. What in one session was a health potion could be poison or a magepotion in the next session. Together with problem one, the lacking collision detection this leads to a slow grind to death.4: The roquelike elements aren't good enough because they aren't really persistent. The point of games like these is that although you die you gain somethinmg from your try at the dungeon that helps you within your next attempt. In Delver this is gold, if you die you get to use the gold you had in your inventorey on the next cahracter and nothing else. This is a problem. Logically you could say that it would bring you forward for your next character so you can buy items to maybe master the dungeon this time.The problem is that you can only buy temporary items that dissapear with your next death. This would mean that you have to do several runs just to grind out gold for that on round that you maybe, maybe not, get trough the dungeon with. That would be if the avaiable items could make a hug impact, wich they don't because they are standart items you could easily find in the dungeon itself. A seller a few levels down selss actually experience potions wich practically means you are buying levels. But they cost 250 Gold per potion and that means a whole lot of goldgrinding runs to maybe be able to buy enough so that it has an impact.Delver clearly needs more persistent rewards that carry over between deaths.Now, why do i still recommend this game?Well, as Delver is kinda in endless Early Access there is hope these things can change. But my bigger reason is that despite the mentioned flaws i honestly have to say that i had a lot of fun for the money the game has cost and that i still feel that i will come back to the game here and there to have some atmospheric, simple fun playing it.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								Delver is a first person action rogue-like where you are delving into a dungeon to fetch the orb and ascend.... Essentially this is Rogue if Rogue was a first person action game. You use various weapons, wands, potions, and food as to transverse down different styles of levels fighting various enemies - some that fly!Some of the best things about this game though is that it does well to allow for pattern recognition from enemies - allowing for skill players to dispatch enemies with deft movement and attacks. Its traps can be somewhat simple, but they can sometimes lead to some interesting situations - and a clever player can always 'trigger' them before stepping on them.In many ways, this is a very simple game as far as first person action rogue-likes go, and it has been somewhat slow to develop - being in Early Access long after Barony for instance was done. It doesn't have multiplayer and it can feel somewhat easy to play and should be easily beaten within the first few tries by more competent players. There is perhaps a bit of a lack in what you can do and experience for the price tag of the game.Overall I do recommend this game, though I wish there was more depth to it. As it is now it lacks somewhat in replayability - which for many players is going to be a glowing problem. But it does have the potential to be a fun little game to play if develop continues on it.

								What I liked about this game... Hmm let me start with the graphics. This game took the cake with the pixely graphics, the look of the pixels the animation blend so well together. You wouldn't expect that with most pixel styled games, half the time the animations are stiff, but this game puts it together beautifully! Next is the action. This isn't a crazy action game, more like a stroll through a dangerous and mysterious dungeon! Yes you encounter multiple enemies and hack and slash at them, very good action content. I recommend this game to all who enjoy a good roguelike action game with beautiful pixel styled art.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								So I just played and finished my very first game of this. And I have to say it's really really fun, even at such an early point in development. It was incredibly tense when I was fighting my way through the enemies in an attempt to reach the surface, using what small resources I had left after getting to the bottom of the dungeon. And the gameplay is just what I want from this kind of Roguelike, you have to learn everything and aren't spoonfed information, you'll have no idea what a Potion does until you drink it, which is great, you can be on very low health and be in the situation of "If I drink this potion will it heal me, or kill me". Learning how attacks interact with each other is fun as well, I used a potion on a Pressure Plate and it exploded, which led me into learning that hitting a potion on the floor turns it into a bomb, very useful considering how far you can throw items. Or that if your Magic Attack hits an Enemies Magic Attack, it will explode both and deal AoE damage. The only thing I never actually figured out was what the Agility stat did. The graphics, which some would call "Lazy", fit the style and genre of the game perfectly because in a Roguelike you don't want to be overloaded with details you want everything to be fairly simple, but good looking, which is what this game achieves. While the graphics aren't realistic, they present a great atmosphere for the game and really help with immersion.The Music is also good, it just quitely sits in the background and blends well with the ambient sounds, not drowning out anything important such as the movement or chatter of enemies.Things I would like to see in the future of this game are:- More varied qualities to accessories, weapons and armour. Like qualities that affect gameplay in a more meaniingful way than just stat changes. Depending how it would influence how the game plays.- Perhaps a way to make potions, using ingredients that you don't know what they do until you use them.- Perhaps a way of recharging wands, as I tended to end up carrying 6 wands around and throwing them away once one ran out. That would mean making wands a bit rarer though.- Some ways to specialise as a character, maybe a class system that have different starting stats and items?- And maybe... mod support if possible? When the game is finished of course.Overall though, even lacking some of the things I would like, this game is incredibly fun and I will probably continue to play it for a while, especially as more updates come.

Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bought this for sale 66% off at $2.50ish during a steam sale. I think this was money well spent for the hour or so of enjoyment I got out of the game. Even buying it at full price, it would have paid for itself.The combat is pretty basic but it works well for the slow paced combat. The visuals are very reminiscent of Minecraft along with all the controls. The inventory system works well for allowing you to collect loot along your trip down the dungeon and the randomized potions give a little risk to using them each time you restart, which is frustrating but in a good way.As for faults, the level/stat system is a little broken as you only need to put points into health for the first five levels and defense the rest to become relatively hard to kill. Ranged combat versus flying enemies, which is when it's needed, is a fools game unless you're using a lightning wand (almost hit scan), as projectiles have travel time and flying enemies juke around way too much to predict their movements. I just found myself running up under them and stabbing upward for a sure hit.Finally, while I died the first time down the dungeon due to trying to figure out the system, I beat the game on the second try. I received a slash screen of text and then the game treated me like I had died. I'm pretty much not going down a third time until there are further updates, but as I said at the start, I got my money's worth already and I recommend a purchase, especially if it's on sale again.TL;DR - It's an enjoyable game but has it's issues. Worth a buy, especially if it's on sale.

The game plays as a soft first-person roguelike with beautiful execution that takes the complex tunnels and potion identifying of traditional games in the genre and simplifies and amplifies it, and assuming with updates from the developer it's only going to get better as time goes on.
