Early Access Review
								Delver is a good game to play if you want to kill an hour or two.Afterwards, it feels like there's no more reason to continue though. The weapons all behave very much the same. You have your slow close combat weapons, your long range, and your long range with flashy colors.I died more than 5 times from random things. Would be walking along, no enemies around and then die suddenly. Then be forced to completely restart which was very frustrating.I feel like this game could be really really fun though. Maybe hide special weapons around the map that you don't find via killing enemies, but instead in secret optional dungeon rooms that have increased traps and perils? Or maybe even have the ability to find totems or statues that can randomize your items, restart the floor, give you full health, bring you down to 1 health, or give you a very special armor. Somesuch like that. It may be a lot of work, too. But it could also be a very cool idea to make a hub town world with vendors and such as there are before you go into the dungeon. And in the hub area, you could get told of other dungeons to go explore as the same character.Still though, if you're looking to kill an hour or two, I say go for it and get this game. Updates are always bringing fixes and features.In it's current form, 6/10. Not perfect, but not too shabby.

Posted: April 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is a fun, first person rogue-like dungeon crawler and it's pretty fun. Even though I beat it after 3 times, I still want to play again. I beat it fast, but it's still in early access, so many things can be changed. Now to the overall score;GAMEPLAY is really fun and satisfying. While I played I developed a tactic for each enemy, taking them out really fast. for example when a worm is about to jump-attack, I wait just the right moment to strike and take it down. 9/10VISUALS is actually pretty good despite the fact it is pixel graphics. However, graphics shouldn't decide if game is good or not, but it's still nice to look at. The inventory system is really easy use and understandable 8.5/10LEVELING. The leveling system cool. I like games when you level up your character and tweak your stats. Even though the most important stat in my opinion is HP, that's how I won the game. But you can only level up one stat by choosing 3 random stats everytime, so it's not always you can level up HP. 8.5/10DIFFICULTY. This game isn't really that hard, but it's not that easy either. For example, the magic wands is really good/ kinda op. I didn't need to level up magic at all, and they were still pretty good. It's in early access, so it can be changed. 8/10So all in all I give this game a 8.6/10. It's not perfect, but it can be improved! If you like rogue-likes buy it. If you like dungeon crawlers, buy it. It's even on sale when I write this review. BUY IT NOW! :D

								I wanted to love Delver, but there isn't enough to fully enjoy. The core mechanics of a "game" exist but it's not fleshed out or given enough attention to be memorable or worth the investment of a 30 minute or more run. The randomness is great at first but you see the same entities many times over with no payoff. There is purposeful stage overlap and retracing to gameplay which isn't a problem, but I wish it was more engaging than "just run". The game world is supposed to be alive around you but it feels frankly as if it never lived at all. If the developers add more content (better starting hub, etc) or find a way to make the current content better(more carry over from each run) maybe it'd be more enjoyable.

Posted: December 2, 2013
Early Access Review
								A nifty little dungeon crawler with adorably chunky monsters that want to kill you in the face.  It sits comfortably halfway between Daggerfall and Doom.  Gameplay is still fairly rudamentary but it's shaped up significantly from the old alpha project.  Combat feels more fair and the itemization is rather generous if you take the time to check each nook.  The music gets a bit repetative, but it's still well done (particularly in the escape).  Hopefully more room blocks will be added to the dungeon layouts, however.  In my limited playtime so far, I encounted the same piece of sewer layout linked to itself four times in a row.  Some further stylization of the dungeon would be nice as well, to help differentiate it from all the other blocky games that have filled the market in recent years.  We'll see what future updates have in store for it, but as it is it's still well worth a look for fans of the genre.

Posted: April 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								    This is a fun adventure game that references the old school roguelikes with many aspects of it's gameplay.      One important feature of this game is permadeath: when you die, you have to start over from the beginning. While this may seem frustrating (and it sometimes is) the game manages to keep itself from becoming boring by having randomly generated dungeons each time you go through. Dungeons come in many flavours, from the big and sprawling, to the small and simple; some dungeons might have cavernous rooms complete with waterfalls, or libraries that seem inviting and warm until a mage appears down a hallway and ends your game for you.   The weapons system, while somewhat basic, has multiple weapons all with their pros and cons. Hammers and maces have a slow speed, but they can knock enemies back; swords are slower than daggers, but they have a better reach. Bows are good for getting rid of the annoying flying eyes, and their more powerful counterpart, wands are just more fun. When you find a weapon in a dungeon it can be made of a variety of materials, including gold - which makes for a very cool looking hammer. They also come in qualities and some weapons may only be good for setting of traps.   The game also has a very good sense of atmosphere, the music goes very well with the style of the game, and the graphics (engine wise) are very good. The lighting is very smooth and the engine allows for some nice effects. The art is very well done and fits with the style of the game very well. This all combines to make the game a very immersive experience and even with the best armour hearing an enemy shout from behind you is enough to make you flinch.    Howevey, as this game is in early access there are some issues with balance, such as mages being extremely powerful, especially on the first level, when you don't have a lot of health. Hopefully all the issues will be fixed in the future and many new features will be added.    Also, some people may point out the lack of a tutorial - while there is a very rudimentary one on a piece of paper in the spawn area, I think this game is pretty well off without a detailed tutorial. It is very rewarding to find out the best way to go about doing something on your own and finding a use for those items that seemed pretty useless in the spawn room...All in all, this is a very fun, albeit short game, but it has good potential for the future and it's replayability means you can enjoy it more than once. I recommend getting this (Especially for $8 US)

Posted: January 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've enjoyed this game, but it's a tenative recommendation I give with the following advice: try rougelike games first, see if you like them. This puppy's more a dog for fans of Ultima Underworld, for those familiar with the game, than someone looking for a first-person, cartoony Diablo. Which *was* the developer's goal and they need to be commended for their efforts: the game, for what it is, is in my opinion a good but (right now at least) somewhat limited game, and one that's still in development besides. See if you like any of the free rougelike games out there- if not Rouge itself. See if you like games with very little plot to speak of (Doom did have a plot; Super Mario Bros. 3 as well). Read up on Delver and games like it just a bit. And thenm when you're ready, take the plunge: $8 is really quite a deal for a charming little pick-me-up game like this (relatively easy deaths means this game is "just one more try" obsession-ready, so bear this in mind too). God speed.

Posted: January 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								"Alright, got the Orb, one final stretch and I'm out of the caves. Is that a skeleton mage? Oh crap, I have to get across this pulley, please don't be a mag- Oh good, it's a warrior. I'll just activate the pulley and shoot at him with my wand. Steady, Aim, Fire!"At that point, my character, level 11 with 30/35 HP remaining falls over, dead from the spell he just shot. The spell was an Ice Blast, a blue slow moving ball that was capable of doing 13-30 damage. Unfortunately, the spell was slower than the pulley I was riding to cross a gaping chasm that the game generated with its unique random dungeon generator. Basically, I spit against the wind and it smacked me in the face.I had collected the orb guarded by a skeleton king and escaped the familiar halls that I had once traveled. Any enemies spared from my golden fire mace greeted me with open fangs and drawn swords alongside the army of skeletons so intent on retrieving what I had taken. I was so close, only for me to fall victim to own spell.At this point, many would be furious. Sure, it's a light rouge-RPG and death is to be expected, but the fact that a spell from your own wand killed you would be enough for most to say the game is horrible and broken. "You shouldn't die from your own attack, that's common sense." One would imagine.But in this case, it isn't. As I descended through the dungeon I would occasionally find these weird eye demons that would hurl themselves at me, shooting fireballs that would make quick work of any would-be adventurer without the proper gear and lack of decent footwork. Once in a while, these demons would be going so fast, their demise wouldn't be by my hand, it would be by their own as they would smashed into their conjured attack. I would laugh, grab any loot dropped and move on. I ignored the fact that an enemy could be hurt by their own spell. If an enemy could slay themselves, why would it be any different for me? Why should I be exempted from this rule?So I had to learn the hard way by adding my corpse to the body count of the dungeon. All that progress was now lost. The past hour, gone because of a mistake I should’ve recognized.9/10

Posted: August 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really like the game. I always love dungeon crawlers like this one, and the older pixel style of the game really appeals to a certain kind of player. Unfortunately, I've noticed a few issues with the game, given its early access status. The random generator for dungeon mapping doesn't always create a dungeon that can be completed. Sometimes you may enter a floor on which progress is impossible though an insurmountable object being generated between you and the next floor, and the game does not let you turn back to leave. This can happen on the first floor, or any floor afterward, no matter how far along in the game you are. A similarly game-breaking bug is the random generation of traps. Floor traps are, as far as I've seen, indestructible. One such trap teleports you. In my case, this one such trap teleported me to the room that the trap blocked the exit of, once again, I had to delete my file and restart.As soon as this game is finished and patched so that such severe bugs don't occur anymore, I have confidence in Delver becoming a truly great game.

Posted: January 28, 2016
Early Access Review
Overview and Gameplay:Delver is a nifty roguelike rpg-light game with the basic idea of "Go into random dungeon, get orb, get out." Very simple premise but it works. Once inside the dungeon you cannot escape until you reach the end and grab the orb, followed by backtracking all the way to the beginning. Environment/UI:The look and feel of the game is very nice and detailed. Animations are fluid, lighting isn't too overpowering and neither are dark areas. I didn't feel the need to use a lantern/candle ever. Basically it's very Minecraft like but with a more SNES RPG style for sprites and you don't destroy/gather the environment. The dungeons are also littered with traps, lava and pits, so watch your step and remember to check behind you if backtracking too far.The UI is very simple: hold X amount of items and asign quick use ones to your "belt" for buttons 1-6. The game won't auto replace multiple of the same item, so don't rely on that if you're in a pinch. Everything is drag and drop, so you can throw away any unused items.Enemies:The enemy sprites have great attack/hit animations and it's very satisfying to splat goblins. Once you figure out how enemy attack animations go though, the difficulty is pretty much removed unless there's an area with a varying amount of enemy types, specifically magic users. Magic hits suck big time - magic animation speeds are very fast and will always hit if too close. Luckily they can be destroyed with your own magic or well-placed arrows.Stats:When you level you'll be given a choice to increase a single stat out of 3 options, however, there are 6-7 main stats in the game. I'm not sure how it selects which 3 to show you, as I've gotten the same option twice in a row and mixed, so it may be random. This can kind of be a pain if you really need more health but don't get the option for 2 levels. Available stats are attack, defense, magic, health, agility, and speed. They are self-explanitory except for magic and agility. Magic will increase the number of charges in wands, not the damage they do. Agility gives you faster movement when holding a charged attack. Items:The weapons and armor are pretty standard - leather, plate, sword, mace, bow, etc. The magic wands are nifty but the low amount of charges makes them more emergency items that are best used against other magic users. All food heals over time and is best used when you're retreating or right after a battle ends. Food is also good for combating poison as they basically cancel out. Weapon attacks can be made stronger by holding the attack longer, but each weapon has it's own timing animations. Getting that down makes strong attacks way easier to land.Potions are terrible. There are a couple different types but each time you load a new game the effects randomly change, so not all red potions will heal. This is a huge gripe as you have to try out each potion every time and essentially waste items so you know what to look for further into the dungeon. Another gripe is that potions do not stack like arrows (neither does food).Gold also drops from enemies, but in such low amounts that on my first successful playthrough I ended up with 774 and wasn't able to use any in the dungeon. The idea is that, when you finish the dungeon, you'll get to use the gold on a second playthrough so you can get some items on a brand new character, but this isn't as fleshed out as it could be. Items do not have any value and cannot be sold, so don't be like me and horde excellent items.Bottom Line:Delver was enjoyable once I got the hang of the items and felt comfortable using a weapon (mace). The visuals are great, animations solid, and the music was enjoyable and matched the asthetic of the game. I recommend the game, however, in it's current state there may not be enough replayability to keep me coming back. Some updates are needed to the UI/items, and if they expand on NPC sellers/items I think it would be even better.3 out of 5 stars/thumbs/pixels

Posted: April 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I seem to be playing a lot of Roguelikes recently, and this game is pretty darn good for Early Access.Your mission is to explore the dungeon and find the orb at the bottommost floor, fighting through groups of people, bugs (ick), bats and skeletons. Get the orb and do your best to escape alive, because everything comes back at you threefold once you pick up the darn thing. The first-person perspective, coupled with a few small corridors and narrow walkways, really give you a mild sense of fear and excitement--you never know what's going to jump out from behind the wall (hopefully not a magic-user).The game is pretty short. For some players, you could run through the whole thing and escape alive in only about 3 attempts. But don't let that deter you, as it is a lot of fun regardless. That being said, I would strongly suggest picking this game up when it's on sale, as there is a lot to be desired. Still, it IS Early Access...Also, sometimes I feel like I'm being cheated. I went down there with around 80 arrows, never found a bow, found the orb instead, tried to escape, made it back up to the first floor and FINALLY found a single bow to use the arrows with. Great...

								This game is amazing and is a must have.  It gives off a very nostaligic vibe thanks to it's 2.5D sprites and 2-3 frame animations. Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you remember old school fps dungeon crawlers? The ones that you have to run on dosbox now? Did you like Elder Scrolls: Daggerfall? Well then Delver is the game for you. It is pretty simple, the RPG mechanics don't go past simple stat upgrades, and equipment, which makes for thinking along the lines of: "do I want to hit really hard, or run really fast, or never die" the way to play. Combine that with rogue-like elements, and you have a very fun game. You can jump in for 10 minutes, and get a great experience. Replayability wise, the game might get dull once you've gotten the orb, however with all the different ways you can go about getting the orb, it will be worth your money. I'd highly reccomend this game to anyone that likes Elder Scrolls: Daggerfall, The Binding of Issac, or any old school fps rpg.

Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Simple Review  here:Delver is a rogue-like dungeon crawler where the player's only goal is to get to the bottom of the dungeon (7th floor), grab the Yithidian Orb, and return to the surface with it. What's the catch? Well I'm glad you asked. As previously stated, there are 7 floors in total. The first two are the Dungeons, the next two are the Caves, the next two are the Sewers, and the final stage is the dreaded Ruins. This game can have a somewhat steep learning curve, but it is very fun because each playthrough is an entirely new experience. Here's why. The dungeons are all procedurally generated (which means you get entirely new maps every time you play), the items one may acquire vary in quality and location, and all potions change in their function. The red potion may be healing or magic resistance the first time through, but it may be poison or physical damage resistance the next time through. These qualities are what make this game a Rogue-like. This is also a First Person game and there are NO PUZZLES for those of you who hate puzzles haha. Pros:+ The graphics are very well done, stylized in a 16-bit, pixelated vibe. + The music is very pleasing and enjoyable. It is fitting for floor's theme and atmospheric as well. + The controls are simple and easy to learn.+ The game makes leaps and bounds with every update provided.+ It has a surprisingly addictive learning curve.+ Difficulty is good enough to where you may finally beat the game one time, but when you go back to try again you can't make it. +Enemy AI is good. The various enemies have various attack patterns and styles, even methods of movement. + A somewhat complex weapon system in which there are several types of weapons such as the bow, wand, hammer (2-hands), and long sword just to name a few. Each weapon has its own knockback, damage, and range. + The leveling system is unique in this game in that you get to choose from 3 randomly chosen stats out of 6 total stats: Agility, Attack, Defense, Health, Magic, and Speed. + Can create various character builds according to the stats you want, the stats your given each level up, and the amount of armor you choose to wear. + Armor affects speed and defense: The more defense, the less speed in general. + Tons of replay value and plenty of good texture packs and mods to extend the game and make it more challenging. . . even adding new types of floors and enemies!+ Items do not carry over after death, but gold does.+ I greatly enjoy how you start at a base camp every time that contains two vendors who can sell you things after you collect enough gold in the dungeon. If you're lucky, you may come a cross a vendor in one of the first two floors as well. Cons:- There are still a few bugs to work out such as items randomly getting stuck in walls and making this atrocious sound that cuts out the music for the rest of your journey. - Another bug would be the bow sometimes passing right through enemies or just bouncing off. Some of the enemies may just have ridiculous hit boxes (looking at you floating eye). - Other than those two bugs, I never really came across anything that was bad or wrong. - Pick your poison here: Runs can take you anywhere from 30 minutes (if you're really good and have lots of experience) to 1 hour and 30 minutes or longer (if you're a noob). - For some players, the luck factor that comes in to play when discovering gear, the distance from the entrance of a floor to the exit of a floor, and the number of enemies that spawn, may not be entirely enjoyable as it will feel as if the odds are against you a bit too strongly at times. Overall, this game is a whole lot of fun and well worth every penny spent. The creator updates relatively often and they are usually massive updates when he does. He keeps everyone informed of his goals with the game and where it is headed. It's a very good challenge and you can quit and pick it back up at any time. I personally love playing it casually while listening to some of my favorite music. It's a very relaxing, but still energetic experience.

								Ive been enjoying this game a lot-  but it is pretty shallow. I see great potential in it! I dig the graphics and really feel this game has huge potential IF the developers  take the time to go the extra mile and give this game more depth. This game needs new rare-rooms monsters items I would also love to see something carry over from your previous life.  A mode to let you keep your stats after each death would be cool! Of course the game would get very easy over time as you get stacked up, but if it was never ending (Or super long) with much harder dungeons and monsters and more epic gear to collect it would be a great way to get you ready for those levels.As it stands now though- I paid 4 bucks- (On sale) and I feel satisfied with what I paid and played. Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver is a fantasic Dungeon crawl for a cold night (or any night really) the environment is immersive, the enemies have gone through some nice AI changes to make them a tad smarter than a tea kettle, some even give a nice jump scare when you round a corner and a spider or Telepathic monster is lurking since they don't always make a sound. oh and Bats and caterpillars seem to drop hilariously large heavy items such as a mace or a complete set of mail armour. Love it, most of the other enemies drop coins or potions or minor weapons and armour. But these guys seem to carry a large mace around with them! lol The envronments are well crafted and quite large. The new maps make the trek more of a challenge as they tend to loop around and take you to cliffs and dead ends sometimes as they are not always straight forward to getting you around the maps.  Also  the maps are randomly generated with a pemadeath element so your never going to have the same playthrough twice as even if you get the same map the items and enemies have also changed and moved around.  The weapons are a standard mish-mash or the usual sort, dagger, sword, hammers, maces and axes, aswell as a few wands. Leveling up is random, your given a choice of 3 skills out of about 6 or so to level up so your not nessasarily able to just level one skill at a time. Ive played through multiple times and had a blast everytime, 10/10 for this one excited to see the changes as they happen

Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Okay, so I originally downloaded this game back during it's open Alpha (Or beta, not entirely sure) stage in development when it was just a free 8-bit thing, and it was amazing. Sure the gameplay was simplistic, but that was to be expected. So a few years later I was kinda suprised that when I found this game was on Steam, as I handn't heard anything about it for a long time. So I bought it, and was amazed with what the game had become. The textures had been changed from 8 to 16 bits, and are really well designed. I'm also loving the tons of new enemies and weapons, as well as the possobility of shops in the overworld now. Admittedly the game is still pretty hard the further you go, so I have yet to have enough gold to test these shops, but it doesn't take anything away from the gameplay. On the note of difficulty, I'm also not sure of how many more dungeons they've added (There was only one in alpha, but that's definetly changed). There are a few issues here and there, (Throwing a fire wand into the water broke the sounds for me) but this game is still in early acess, so that's kinda to be expected. But compared to alot of the stuff that is on early acess, this is easily one of the best things I've seen in here to date.

Posted: April 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have owned this game on mobile for ome time now, and I just recently bought the game on Steam. Let me say, this game does not disappoint. I got the game on sale, but the price of 7.99$ USD is totally reasonable. Here is why:-Great, Motivated Developers (Updates are Frequent, but not too frequent. I.E. Once a month-ish)-Loads of Combat (Lots of different weapons to try, ranging from Bows to Maces)-Lots of Hidden Lore (Notes are scattered about the Dungeon, hinting about the games Lore)-Lots of Monsters (Fight Mobs ranging from Spiders to One-Eyed Flying Things)-Appealing Graphics (Nice Retro feel, texture packs are avalible)-Wonderful Music (Very peaceful at times, makes you want to adventure)-Procedurly Generated Dungeons and Caves (Caves and Dungeons are Generated on spawn, every world is different)The frequent updates, music, and graphics of this game really get you in the mood for dungeon running, and it feals so rewarding to climb down the ladder to the next floor. Prepare to sink many hours trekking through dungeons, and when your character dies in an epic battle against a small bat, to instantly set off on another trip through a whole new dungeon.My only complaint is the fact that the scroll wheel doesn't allow you to navigate the hotbar.Also, saw a Doge painting. 10/10

Posted: April 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Short review: If you like dungeon exploring and the challenge of perma-death, in a game that manages to balance that challenge with enough play to keep you coming back, you shoudl check Delver out.Long review: The graphics are "Minecraft-like" for lack of a better way to put it. They're 3d 16 bit, nothing fancy, but they work. It definitely adds to the retro feel.The gameplay is the same first person dungeon exploration that harkens back to Ultima Underworld. It's balanced and challenging. There is a learning curve but you will find yourself delving deeper on each try and more importantly, wanting to try again after each death.This is one of the few perma-death games that get it right. It isn't frustrating but also is not easy.  Don't get me wrong, one moment of stupid can cause a restart but the build to your character is balanced with the difficulty in such a way as to make you avoid mistakes and almost always understand exactly why you died when/where you did. This balance is what makes me want to keep coming back and keeps me trying to delve deeper into the dungeon and hone my skills. I've tied a lot of these rogue-like games with perma-death recently and this one definitely stands out a a diamond in the rough.

Posted: April 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's not entirely unlike Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup, in the style and story (1. Reach bottom of dungeon; 2. Grab shiny orb of arbitrary unexplained power; 3. GTFO while being pursued by respawning enemies). However, Delver is a much shorter and more straightforward game, and is a real-time roguelike rather than a turn-based one. But despite, or perhaps because of, its short length (7 floors, easily completable in an hour or two) it is incredibly fun. It has the right amount of RNG; enough to keep things fresh with new layouts and items, but not so much that you can ever really get wrecked by random factors beyond your control. Every run feels winnable; every death feels like it could have been avoided if you had just played better. Plus it has a level editor now, and is still under active development, so there's lots of potential for more things in the future.

Posted: September 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver is a cool dungeon game.Delver offers different weapons, armour, potions and different equipment.The game offers great old school graphics which makes me feel nostalgic at times.With the combination of FPS view and the use of different abilities and stats makes the game much more enjoyable.The game offers the player to chose what kind of character YOU would want to develop to, Magics, Attack etc.The rpg-dungeon style is great it makes the player want to play some more and to finish the gameI found that the magics were really OP. Even though it is good it is extremely strong. I think that the damage of wands is much to strong and may need a slight nerf.I have played the game a lot and have only found one thing slighty wrong. This game is worth the buy it is great and has some old school touches.8.5/10 rating.

Posted: March 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Excellent first-person, rogue-like, not too pixelated-pixelated, dungeon explorer. I love the music and how some enemies seem to come out of  nowhere. This game is great if you like an fps/rpg/rogue-like, minimalist game and don't easily get nausiated from erratic user-mouse movement (because that's kinda my style). It's less pixelated than Home so it doesn't mess with my vision once I look away from my screen. Although when enemies get right in front of your face they get a little distorted but I'm sure that was intended by the developers and adds a nice flavor to the gameplay. Overall, super fun. One of the best early access games I've purchased regardless of the fact that I bought it on sale. There has been a little bit of clipping through walls (throwing items directly into a wall at about a 30 degree angle and hallways that loop around) but it's in parts that I can't tell if it was intentional or not so this is not a negative comment, more so a random add-on to my review.

Posted: March 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								TLDR: An absolutely fantastic dungeon crawl that is casual and smooth, and feels more like a finished small team indie game than something in early access.Gameplay takes less than a minute or two to get into and is helped by the butter smooth controls and simple control scheme. Attacking, either with magic, a melee weapon or a bow (when you find one) is simple but satisfying with the casual nature of the game.Loot is plentiful and  takes after the genre of roguelikes because items must be used to figure out their effects. The simple hotbar system popular these days lets you see what your useful items are but provides challenge at later levels because potions and scrolls don't stack, leaving you with the choice to equip the scroll of resist magic you might need or the extra healing potion so you don't die.Easy to get into, and hard to pull yourself away from, Delver is a diamond in the rough and offers fun in spades for casual dungeon crusaders.

								Its Early Access so I'm sure theres lots of things that can happen, but I'm not ready to say its something I'd reccommend. Its been in production for three years and seems like it has a lot to go to make it interesting for more than a couple runthroughs. Random Dungeon Crawling Rogue-Like Game. Its missing something big and its a combination of the mechanics and lack of really any substance that wont let me enjoy it as much as I feel I could. Pros: Completely random dungeon that works well. RPG Elements. Roguelike, so you never know what you're getting or if you have any chance to succeed. Money Carries over after you die.Cons: Unrefined interface, no story, visuals are hard on eyes trying to focus between like the 16 bit characters and semi 3D environment, been in development for a long time. No real drive to play through more than a few times.Overall, i'm not sure what can be added to make it more interesting. The Dev is looking for feedback, but the biggest thing would be to fix the cons. Not sure you you do that with the short playtimes. Why are you there, what are you doing, what is driving you, who are these people, what is the reward, what do I do with all this broken and useless stuff you accumulate, are some good questions to start answering.-Comiccomwww.thecomic-community.com

Posted: August 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is a fantastic game of procedural dungeon crawling, satisfiying real time combat, and exploration. Delver contains smooth RPG-like combat, where by charging your attack makes it more likely to hit your target (guarenteeing a hit when fully charged); a mysterious setting of an anchient tower holding one of the greatest treasures known; and oogles of replay value.Even though the game is currently in Early Access Beta, it feels well polished, and expertly crafted. Every update adds in more generation to every level in the game, and there are very few if any bugs to be found. The game has a very fair-unfair bipolar, in the early levels, the enemies are relatively easy to dispatch, but if they land a hit, it can take a sizable amount of health away; and towards the end, your going to run out of health a LOT.Delver is a relatively short game; you trek through 10 levels per playthrough of ever increasing difficulty, fight and defeat (as far as I am aware) a single boss, and make an excruciatingly hard, and harrowing journey back up to the surface from whence you came. The final level is the MOST unfair and difficult level in the game, and is probably the one and only constant level throughout your journey, as it appears unchanged through each playthrough. It introduces several enemy types not seen before on any level, and ALL of them hit really, really hard. I have never successfully managed to beat the final boss, and have only made it to him twice.All in all, it is very challenging, and you will die a LOT, but it never feels like you couldn't stop it from happening. Delver is an incredibly fun, semi-addicting, dungeon crawl with danger lurking around every corner, and an unfair boss level.

								It just keeps getting better.  The new areas are frickin creepy. The AI now shoots at you from accross the area which was totally unexpected.  The loot drops are more balanced. All in all, I have been in love with this game for 3ish years now before even the art changed. And still it fancinates me more so than any big budget triple A title.  I even found myself ducking my head to the side to try to avoid spell bursts flying at me!  Better luck next time delver! GG 1,000,000/10

Posted: August 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really like the game. I always love dungeon crawlers like this one, and the older pixel style of the game really appeals to a certain kind of player. Unfortunately, I've noticed a few issues with the game, given its early access status. The random generator for dungeon mapping doesn't always create a dungeon that can be completed. Sometimes you may enter a floor on which progress is impossible though an insurmountable object being generated between you and the next floor, and the game does not let you turn back to leave. This can happen on the first floor, or any floor afterward, no matter how far along in the game you are. A similarly game-breaking bug is the random generation of traps. Floor traps are, as far as I've seen, indestructible. One such trap teleports you. In my case, this one such trap teleported me to the room that the trap blocked the exit of, once again, I had to delete my file and restart.As soon as this game is finished and patched so that such severe bugs don't occur anymore, I have confidence in Delver becoming a truly great game.

Posted: December 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is easily one of the most immediately enjoyable games I've played.  It takes the familiar rogue-like formula and gives it an unusual first-person treatment and a surprising amount of depth from its seemingly simple system.  If you are a fan of hack-and-slash, stat-based RPGs, rouge-likes, or just a quick, accessible action game, Delver delivers.  My only gripes are with the difficult inventory menu.  It would be nice if the game paused while it was active and it's hard to get in and out of quickly.  I haven't found a way of identifying potions besides trial and error, and with limited health restoration, this can be deadly.  Random death is not good.Also, there are places where jumping feels needed, but there seems to be no jump feature.  It never breaks the game, but I notice the lack of it.

Posted: December 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing! It reminds so much of Pixel Dungeon, except it's first person which makes it so cool! I love how simple the mechanics are, and especially how the food works. I also love the fact that you don't know what potions do until you drink them, and that traps do random things. I wouldn't say it's worth the $8 at the moment, but I am really glad that I bought it because it has so much potential to be even better.Some things I would recommend would be:- Option to sell items at the shops (hate to carry around 2nd best gear and have to leave it lying around)- Smaller minimap marker (the current arrow is way too big)- Mouse wheel to scroll through belt (using the numbers takes your hand off of WASD, which can get you killed since you can't move then)- Overworld map with multiple towns (then you can have a choice between what dungeons you want to go into, with each town having a dungeon that leans towards a different theme, like caves, bandits, etc.)- Jumping Maybe (the girl with the staff can jump, why can't I?)- COOP!!!! (this game would be awesome with a friend! although, I don't really know how you would pull that off...)These are just suggestions and I think the game could be even more amazing with them implemented (well, mostly the mouse scroll, minimap, and selling).

Posted: December 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is easily one of the most immediately enjoyable games I've played.  It takes the familiar rogue-like formula and gives it an unusual first-person treatment and a surprising amount of depth from its seemingly simple system.  If you are a fan of hack-and-slash, stat-based RPGs, rouge-likes, or just a quick, accessible action game, Delver delivers.  My only gripes are with the difficult inventory menu.  It would be nice if the game paused while it was active and it's hard to get in and out of quickly.  I haven't found a way of identifying potions besides trial and error, and with limited health restoration, this can be deadly.  Random death is not good.Also, there are places where jumping feels needed, but there seems to be no jump feature.  It never breaks the game, but I notice the lack of it.

Posted: January 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								"Alright, got the Orb, one final stretch and I'm out of the caves. Is that a skeleton mage? Oh crap, I have to get across this pulley, please don't be a mag- Oh good, it's a warrior. I'll just activate the pulley and shoot at him with my wand. Steady, Aim, Fire!"At that point, my character, level 11 with 30/35 HP remaining falls over, dead from the spell he just shot. The spell was an Ice Blast, a blue slow moving ball that was capable of doing 13-30 damage. Unfortunately, the spell was slower than the pulley I was riding to cross a gaping chasm that the game generated with its unique random dungeon generator. Basically, I spit against the wind and it smacked me in the face.I had collected the orb guarded by a skeleton king and escaped the familiar halls that I had once traveled. Any enemies spared from my golden fire mace greeted me with open fangs and drawn swords alongside the army of skeletons so intent on retrieving what I had taken. I was so close, only for me to fall victim to own spell.At this point, many would be furious. Sure, it's a light rouge-RPG and death is to be expected, but the fact that a spell from your own wand killed you would be enough for most to say the game is horrible and broken. "You shouldn't die from your own attack, that's common sense." One would imagine.But in this case, it isn't. As I descended through the dungeon I would occasionally find these weird eye demons that would hurl themselves at me, shooting fireballs that would make quick work of any would-be adventurer without the proper gear and lack of decent footwork. Once in a while, these demons would be going so fast, their demise wouldn't be by my hand, it would be by their own as they would smashed into their conjured attack. I would laugh, grab any loot dropped and move on. I ignored the fact that an enemy could be hurt by their own spell. If an enemy could slay themselves, why would it be any different for me? Why should I be exempted from this rule?So I had to learn the hard way by adding my corpse to the body count of the dungeon. All that progress was now lost. The past hour, gone because of a mistake I should’ve recognized.9/10

Posted: December 6, 2013
Early Access Review
								Tremendously fun so far! I love the graphical style and the music. It's a simple game that has great potential and I hope that it will be continued to be expanded by its author. As it is, it's relatively short. I finished it on my third try. The first time I didn't know what I was doing and died quickly. The second time I was more careful and made it to the end, but didn't realize I was near the end, and so I died again. The third time I was prepared, and beat the game. The gold / buying stuff is handled in an interesting way; the gold you collect can only be used to buy things in the NEXT game you play. So while you don't keep levels, items, etc after you die, you do gain an advantage the next time. There are a few annoying things, which will hopefully get fixed in later versions. Some are glitches, like enemies getting stuck in walls. Others are interface things; I found switching between weapons in the middle of combat didn't always work as well as I'd like. However I'd say that Delver is worth buying ... I probably won't play it again until it's next update, but I'm looking forward to doing so.

Posted: December 2, 2013
Early Access Review
								A nifty little dungeon crawler with adorably chunky monsters that want to kill you in the face.  It sits comfortably halfway between Daggerfall and Doom.  Gameplay is still fairly rudamentary but it's shaped up significantly from the old alpha project.  Combat feels more fair and the itemization is rather generous if you take the time to check each nook.  The music gets a bit repetative, but it's still well done (particularly in the escape).  Hopefully more room blocks will be added to the dungeon layouts, however.  In my limited playtime so far, I encounted the same piece of sewer layout linked to itself four times in a row.  Some further stylization of the dungeon would be nice as well, to help differentiate it from all the other blocky games that have filled the market in recent years.  We'll see what future updates have in store for it, but as it is it's still well worth a look for fans of the genre.

Early Access Review
								A nifty little early access game that is sure to entertain those who love the classic rougelike genre.The pixel graphics are detailed and well made which give a certain old school aesthetic adding to the tone and athmosphere of the gameplay.Some people have been worried about the current state of development for the game. Has a lot of promise to be very fun, I just feel like it's missing something to make it really stand out.

Posted: November 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								--I have bought this game through the Humble Bundle store and thus my playtime here on Steam does not reflect my total playtime of the game.--This is a praiseworthy game. It's like playing a classic roguelike, the only difference being it's realtime and combat factors in your skill. Combat plays very similarly to Skyrim, and once you understand how to move and chain your attacks I think it's a very solid system.In terms of loot and magic, it's good. Once you get past the first three floors you will start finding more interesting pieces of equipment.Graphics are simple but they have a lot of work behind them. Art and lighting are very nice. Sound effects are good enough for the job.The music is better in some places than in others, but I'd say it's pretty good (especially the more atmospheric pieces down below).The game as it is is a great bargain. It's a 100% finished game as it stands. And it's good. And it's still being updated.

Posted: April 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I believe this game has a pretty solid base. Graphical style reminded me of Ultima Underworld, combat felt like Magicite combined with Minecraft, and that all got dropped into a simple stat roguelike game. Combat was pretty fair and can be pretty unforgiving if you aren't careful. That said, I believe this game needs some serious difficulty boosts via bosses and more dangerous traps. Cleared the whole game in roughly 110 minutes on the first try. Second thing I feel would make it more interesting would be the addition of more secret doors and maybe optional puzzles.

Posted: April 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's not entirely unlike Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup, in the style and story (1. Reach bottom of dungeon; 2. Grab shiny orb of arbitrary unexplained power; 3. GTFO while being pursued by respawning enemies). However, Delver is a much shorter and more straightforward game, and is a real-time roguelike rather than a turn-based one. But despite, or perhaps because of, its short length (7 floors, easily completable in an hour or two) it is incredibly fun. It has the right amount of RNG; enough to keep things fresh with new layouts and items, but not so much that you can ever really get wrecked by random factors beyond your control. Every run feels winnable; every death feels like it could have been avoided if you had just played better. Plus it has a level editor now, and is still under active development, so there's lots of potential for more things in the future.

Posted: March 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Excellent first-person, rogue-like, not too pixelated-pixelated, dungeon explorer. I love the music and how some enemies seem to come out of  nowhere. This game is great if you like an fps/rpg/rogue-like, minimalist game and don't easily get nausiated from erratic user-mouse movement (because that's kinda my style). It's less pixelated than Home so it doesn't mess with my vision once I look away from my screen. Although when enemies get right in front of your face they get a little distorted but I'm sure that was intended by the developers and adds a nice flavor to the gameplay. Overall, super fun. One of the best early access games I've purchased regardless of the fact that I bought it on sale. There has been a little bit of clipping through walls (throwing items directly into a wall at about a 30 degree angle and hallways that loop around) but it's in parts that I can't tell if it was intentional or not so this is not a negative comment, more so a random add-on to my review.

								Delver is that one game you just can't beat. When you start playing you're not quite sure how anything works. Potions are random, how much health does this item give, how do I shot wand.After awhile you manage to save some gold up, learn the mechanics and build a idea of how you're going to build your character. Stats are random when you level up so every time you level you're always hoping for the perfect stat for what you want to do.Finally you've made it to the final boss! You defeat him mercilessly and take the Orb thinking "YES! FINALLY! I've beat Delver!" As you're told you must return to the surface to finalise your quest. Well, I wish you luck in retreiving that orb because ever floor you visit is a heart racing experience!

Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is exactly what it looks like, except for the end area. You descend 6 levels, have to pick up an orb, and re-climb them all to get out. When you pick up that orb, you have to deal with infinitely re-spawning enemies throughout the 6 levels, and all the care and patience you took in dealing with them before flies out the window. You leveled only health and made sure I had the best weapons, armor, and healing items you could have before taking the orb. It does not matter. You are swarmed with flying skulls that you cannot outrun and must fight. As you do so, Skeleton mages bombard you with magic from beyond the game's very tiny draw distance, and you die. In a game about resource managemeant and dungeon delving, rushing things leads to death, and the game forces you to do so.I do not recommend this game, and doubt it will be fixed.

Early Access Review
								Delver is hard, entertaining and beautiful. The areas are generated randomly, and each level you have to build up your character choosing between three random stats (exemple : you have to choose between health, speed and agility).This is exactly what I was expecting about the game. This is currently the 0.7, so it's likely the game will get deeper. Just take the game for the atmosphere (the game is really REALLY beautiful if you love the old school graphics), the gameplay (potions on the ground explode when you hit them, the traps can be activated with beer mugs, just so you know), and the difficulty (even first fights are easy, the game will kill you at any mistake you will do).

Posted: December 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing! It reminds so much of Pixel Dungeon, except it's first person which makes it so cool! I love how simple the mechanics are, and especially how the food works. I also love the fact that you don't know what potions do until you drink them, and that traps do random things. I wouldn't say it's worth the $8 at the moment, but I am really glad that I bought it because it has so much potential to be even better.Some things I would recommend would be:- Option to sell items at the shops (hate to carry around 2nd best gear and have to leave it lying around)- Smaller minimap marker (the current arrow is way too big)- Mouse wheel to scroll through belt (using the numbers takes your hand off of WASD, which can get you killed since you can't move then)- Overworld map with multiple towns (then you can have a choice between what dungeons you want to go into, with each town having a dungeon that leans towards a different theme, like caves, bandits, etc.)- Jumping Maybe (the girl with the staff can jump, why can't I?)- COOP!!!! (this game would be awesome with a friend! although, I don't really know how you would pull that off...)These are just suggestions and I think the game could be even more amazing with them implemented (well, mostly the mouse scroll, minimap, and selling).

Posted: December 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is one of the few games I bought early on during the early access phase and can say I'm glad I did. Each update has brought improvements and squashed bugs. The devs also haven't just decided to abandon the game or completely change what they were going for in the first place. They just keep improving it and that alone is enough for me to recommend this game. The random level generation is some of the best I've seen in the genre thus far. I enjoy the art style and music as well. Its easy to get into but hard to master it. I still haven't made a single escape after 25 hours logged. In short, if you like crawling random dungeons in first person and don't mind the art style, then this is definitely something to pick up. Even at full price I highly recommend it. Underrated game by far IMO.

								I held of buying this for quite a while because I just wasn't sure.  STUPID move.  I enjoy this game WAY more than I expected.  I'd even say they could have charged more and I'd still be happy with it.  Such great fun to give in and see how long you last. Being an RPG I just have that desire.It's only a few bucks.  Just buy it already.

Posted: January 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is seriously what one would call a Rogue-like done right! With procedurally generated levels you will find yourself facing new challenges with every run. Comparatively I would say that it is a great homage to games like Ultima Underworld. Your mission is simple enough, retrieve the treasure on the deepest level and then escape, but this game never really feels redundant in any way.Furthermore this game is CONSTANTLY being tweaked and improved. I've seen level layouts improved tremendouly, I've seen new music tracks added, new floors added and new challenges added. You will constantly find yourself juggling your strategies ranging from engaging enemies in hand-to-hand combat to picking off tricky enemies with a bow to firing powerful bolts from your various wands against tougher enemies.Very intense, very satisfying and very fun. Buy it now!

Posted: January 28, 2016
Early Access Review
Overview and Gameplay:Delver is a nifty roguelike rpg-light game with the basic idea of "Go into random dungeon, get orb, get out." Very simple premise but it works. Once inside the dungeon you cannot escape until you reach the end and grab the orb, followed by backtracking all the way to the beginning. Environment/UI:The look and feel of the game is very nice and detailed. Animations are fluid, lighting isn't too overpowering and neither are dark areas. I didn't feel the need to use a lantern/candle ever. Basically it's very Minecraft like but with a more SNES RPG style for sprites and you don't destroy/gather the environment. The dungeons are also littered with traps, lava and pits, so watch your step and remember to check behind you if backtracking too far.The UI is very simple: hold X amount of items and asign quick use ones to your "belt" for buttons 1-6. The game won't auto replace multiple of the same item, so don't rely on that if you're in a pinch. Everything is drag and drop, so you can throw away any unused items.Enemies:The enemy sprites have great attack/hit animations and it's very satisfying to splat goblins. Once you figure out how enemy attack animations go though, the difficulty is pretty much removed unless there's an area with a varying amount of enemy types, specifically magic users. Magic hits suck big time - magic animation speeds are very fast and will always hit if too close. Luckily they can be destroyed with your own magic or well-placed arrows.Stats:When you level you'll be given a choice to increase a single stat out of 3 options, however, there are 6-7 main stats in the game. I'm not sure how it selects which 3 to show you, as I've gotten the same option twice in a row and mixed, so it may be random. This can kind of be a pain if you really need more health but don't get the option for 2 levels. Available stats are attack, defense, magic, health, agility, and speed. They are self-explanitory except for magic and agility. Magic will increase the number of charges in wands, not the damage they do. Agility gives you faster movement when holding a charged attack. Items:The weapons and armor are pretty standard - leather, plate, sword, mace, bow, etc. The magic wands are nifty but the low amount of charges makes them more emergency items that are best used against other magic users. All food heals over time and is best used when you're retreating or right after a battle ends. Food is also good for combating poison as they basically cancel out. Weapon attacks can be made stronger by holding the attack longer, but each weapon has it's own timing animations. Getting that down makes strong attacks way easier to land.Potions are terrible. There are a couple different types but each time you load a new game the effects randomly change, so not all red potions will heal. This is a huge gripe as you have to try out each potion every time and essentially waste items so you know what to look for further into the dungeon. Another gripe is that potions do not stack like arrows (neither does food).Gold also drops from enemies, but in such low amounts that on my first successful playthrough I ended up with 774 and wasn't able to use any in the dungeon. The idea is that, when you finish the dungeon, you'll get to use the gold on a second playthrough so you can get some items on a brand new character, but this isn't as fleshed out as it could be. Items do not have any value and cannot be sold, so don't be like me and horde excellent items.Bottom Line:Delver was enjoyable once I got the hang of the items and felt comfortable using a weapon (mace). The visuals are great, animations solid, and the music was enjoyable and matched the asthetic of the game. I recommend the game, however, in it's current state there may not be enough replayability to keep me coming back. Some updates are needed to the UI/items, and if they expand on NPC sellers/items I think it would be even better.3 out of 5 stars/thumbs/pixels

Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Just played for a few minutes and WOW! This is a great modernized throwback of RPG, dungeon Delving goodness. I'll be playing this more. Oh, and be careful. If you hit some potions, they explode. (ouch!)Update: MANY hours later...Guys 'n gals, buy this game. Srsly. I thoroughly enjoy Delver and I own it on Android as well. The mobile version is a bit behind the PC/Mac version, but definitely worth it. Let's be honest about rogue-likes: they're a dime a dozen. So many rogue wannabes on all platforms. So that begs the question: What makes Delver stand out? I'll sum it up in a short list.1. Atmosphere - music, environment, decoration, ambiance. They nailed it. 2. Mechanics - the gameplay is super simple but somehow I don't feel it's repetetive. 3. Monster variety - See #2; the variety of monster types and attacks keeps combat feeling fresh.4. Inventory/RPG aspects - The inventory is simple but covers all the bases. Easy-peasy, but deep eough now that they have rings, amulets, off-hand (shield, candle, etc.)That's my $.02. This game is a blast. Delver has improved upon the basic RPG/rogue elements, but not so much as to lose the heart and soul of the genre. Highly recommended.

Posted: December 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm really happy I picked up Delver. I had low expectations, but Delver has turned out to be one of the best roguelike dungeon crawlers I've played in quite a while. It's simple, and the graphics harken back to Daggerfall days, but it shines where it counts:- Dungeons are randomly generated (with some exceptions) and feel WORTH exploring. Maps are loaded with crevasses, bridges, hidden rooms, lava, underground lakes, traps, and more. Many maps have a 3D element to them, with bridges or loopbacks bringing you under or over an area you just walked through, or dark passages descending into gloom. If you're a completionist, there is true value in exploring every niche and nook, as the game will reward you with life-saving loot!- Loot! The loot system has more depth than you might guess. It's not Diablo, but there are some elements of the random-loot system here. The game will surprise you with finely crafted items from time to time, or weapons with elemental attacks, usually with some negative trait alongside (Broken 1-3 dmg dagger, with +3 ice damage). You have just enough space in your inventory that by dungeon level 5-6, you might have a full load (and no junk). This means careful inventory management.- Permadeth! You only die once, however you keep some of your money after death. This is useful in shops.Some other things to like about Delver:- Runs ridiculous framerates on my Macbook Pro and never even turns on the fan! My poor laptop isn't much of a gaming rig, but Delver apparently doesn't need one. It's easily the fastest and most responsive FPS-view game I own.- Loads and quits in seconds. You can boot the game and be playing in less than 10 seconds. To quit: ESC, Save, ESC drops you straight to desktop in about 3 seconds!Conclusion: Delver is an excellent choice for people who like RPG's, roguelikes, and exploration. It's lighthearted, but not dumbed-down or easy.

Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought the game because it looked like fun and because I like Rogue-like games, but hell was I surprised how fun it is. Its really addicting and defenetly worth its price. It has awesome music, an easy game concept, it has smooth and simple controlls and an incredibly well created atmosphere. In addition to that it has a good replay value, because it doesnt really get you angry when you die. And also it has a touch of "looting and leveling" combined with the desire of exploring these random generated floors. And its simple graphics have a charm because they are mixed with modern shading- and ligh- effects. And in some areas like the sewer(3rd screenshot) it features this fog which I personally like because it just creates a really nice atmosphere. The atmosphere of the game feels right, the gameplay feels right, and so does the whole game. It sadly doesnt have much of a story, but thats pretty normal for rogue-like games.- Sadly the game still has a few bugs, for example: you can get stuck in certain areas(like the sewer), but you can just go in the folder of the savestates and then change your x,y and z coordinates with an editor.(-> Also the game has lots of mods etc, and it is very easy to mod the game, because its all open source(the game also has a level editor))So in conclusion I can say that the game itself is alot of fun and that it is a fair game with nice gameplay, a replay value and a great atmosphere. You might stumble upon some bugs, but its an early access game and these bugs are usually fixably by the player him-/her-self, so that isnt much of a negativ thing. In my opinion the game is a really well made indie/rogue-like game which I had much fun with. But in the end it is up to YOU if you are going to purchase it or not,either way, have a nice day!

Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								OH man.  OH ok.  I think I am just broken in a way that makes me love this game a whole lot,  First thing, any random dungeon game gets my attention.   Second, any first person dungeoneering thing gets my attention.   So this is both and it's really good.  The art style is like some you have seen before but it is sweet.  Sweet in a way that evokes a certian feeling that other games that use a similar graphical tone really can't do very well.   Not sure how many folks are involved here, I know one might or might not be named Chad, but whoever does the art loves this game.  The fidelity of such would allow for one person to do a whole lot of work to enter in their own perfect vision of the art presentation for the game, and that is great.  By accident or by design it feels to me like the dungeon and the caves (the two locales I have seen so far) are part of cohesive whole that I really like.  The monsters and the npc enemies have good personality, and the sound assets created/selected for them fit very well.  Details regarding the movement of the character and his/her weapons lend the whole game a satisfying weight that just really scratches things that I  like to get scratched.  Combat has a dance like quailty that really changes based on the monster/enemy encountered.   After that it requires a bit of thinking that is easy to do usually but has lots of fun twists invovling number of enemies/elevations/weapons owned or currently using...  meaning that you will be rolling out hard one moment only to have yourself chased down into hard corners, stomping onto pressure plates and getting killed by traps you navigaed deftly only a minute before. Delver is really worth your time and money, and there should be more games like it.  Here's hoping that Chad and whoever make a mint of dollars and buy huge houses.

Posted: May 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								(First of all, in the time that this was written, the game had just received an update after nearly a year, this is because one of the developers had a baby and they had to pause in the development. So if you read any more negative reviews that were made before or around the time this review was made, if they mention anything about the developers not updating, this is why.)Delver is a simple roguelike dungeon crawler that is, I believe, heavily influenced by games like DOOM and Zelda.The objective of the game is to enter a procedurally generated dungeon (Different every time) that consists of several floors with different themes, get the treasure, and return to the surface safely.I don't want to spoil to much, because Delver, I think, is supposed to give you a feeling of wonder, suspense, and the unknown. And, despite being very simple, I feel it somehow does this very well, even after playing the game multiple times. Which I think is why I love it so much. The game is somewhat difficult, maybe even unfair at times, but hey, why would the enemy make it fair in the first place?And also, that is part of the mystery, sometimes, dungeons are full of loot and as you make your way down, you will eventually become nearly invincible, other times, you really have to just make do what you have, and sometimes the traps and the general layout of the dungeon is a real pain in the butt. so, basically, the games difficulty is different EVERY TIME. Which, personally, I think is brilliant. But of course, I highly doubt anyone will be having any competitions with this for $10,000 anytime soon. Which is OK.I cannot express the feeling of winning this, especially for the first time. It makes my day even more than cookies do.Which is saying a lot. I challenge you to beat Delver, if you dare. But remember, it was hidden away for a reason.Edit: Some screenshots I took:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=765355710http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=765356107http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=765355965

Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								A nifty little early access game that is sure to entertain those who love the classic rougelike genre.The pixel graphics are detailed and well made which give a certain old school aesthetic adding to the tone and athmosphere of the gameplay.Some people have been worried about the current state of development for the game. Let me assure you that while this project had gone into Limbo in the past, since the last couple of months the small developer team has made the effort to increase their transparency with the community and has begun doing weekly streams to show the current state of development. That does not however imply that this game may again fall into development hell.Therefore in it's current state I feel that this game is worth the money, however i advise those with less money to spend on games to wait for it to be fully released or pick it up during a sale.Lastly, I believe that while I find this game very enjoyable, people who are not fans of permadeath and rougelike mechanics may find the game offputting.

Posted: March 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Its Early Access so I'm sure theres lots of things that can happen, but I'm not ready to say its something I'd reccommend. Its been in production for three years and seems like it has a lot to go to make it interesting for more than a couple runthroughs. Random Dungeon Crawling Rogue-Like Game. Its missing something big and its a combination of the mechanics and lack of really any substance that wont let me enjoy it as much as I feel I could. Pros: Completely random dungeon that works well. RPG Elements. Roguelike, so you never know what you're getting or if you have any chance to succeed. Money Carries over after you die.Cons: Unrefined interface, no story, visuals are hard on eyes trying to focus between like the 16 bit characters and semi 3D environment, been in development for a long time. No real drive to play through more than a few times.Overall, i'm not sure what can be added to make it more interesting. The Dev is looking for feedback, but the biggest thing would be to fix the cons. Not sure you you do that with the short playtimes. Why are you there, what are you doing, what is driving you, who are these people, what is the reward, what do I do with all this broken and useless stuff you accumulate, are some good questions to start answering.-Comiccomwww.thecomic-community.com

Posted: August 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really like the game. I always love dungeon crawlers like this one, and the older pixel style of the game really appeals to a certain kind of player. Unfortunately, I've noticed a few issues with the game, given its early access status. The random generator for dungeon mapping doesn't always create a dungeon that can be completed. Sometimes you may enter a floor on which progress is impossible though an insurmountable object being generated between you and the next floor, and the game does not let you turn back to leave. This can happen on the first floor, or any floor afterward, no matter how far along in the game you are. A similarly game-breaking bug is the random generation of traps. Floor traps are, as far as I've seen, indestructible. One such trap teleports you. In my case, this one such trap teleported me to the room that the trap blocked the exit of, once again, I had to delete my file and restart.As soon as this game is finished and patched so that such severe bugs don't occur anymore, I have confidence in Delver becoming a truly great game.

Posted: April 10
Early Access Review
								The reason for the low play time is because i play it before steam version...Ok, Where do I begin? This game is a thrill! You shoot, you slash, you have a blast (quick delver rhyme) You play as the delve person, The dungeon has many floors that you must conquer to win the game. There are better weapons and armor to get, I enjoy the simple graphic, sometimes the spider scares me and I need to look away for a moment! it has thrills such as this! sometime the bat come and hit me and I Jump in my seat with a startle, "go to hell bat!" I blabber. I feel for the people I kill in the dungeon, sometimes I kill on sight, This make me realize that i have not given the victim the benefit of the doubt, what if they are friend? Another delve person... This thought haunts me, give me cold sweats. Con (3)-Blood-Scare-Cold sweatsPro (5)-Fun graphic-Sword and bow slashery-Many floor-Find the new weapons-Simple level up system (stat)3 and 5, good balance! for a 7.5/10 score for the game! fun and good!

Posted: June 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is fun and intuitive but I have to say I docked points for finding a trap in a hallway I couldn't avoid in any way; The game doesn't allow you to jump and the way the tile was positioned it wouldn't let me pass without walking over the plate. Having to budget health for gauranteed damage from traps in a roguelike is like trying to pay your mortgage payment with dryer lint. You just don't have the ability to do that. However, I will be willing to play the game some more if I discover that was a very uncommon situation; IE, up until the point I encounter that problem again. If you enjoy roguelikes and you really liked the Might & Magic 1st person adventure games, you'll enjoy Delver.Update (Spoiler Warning): It is possible to deal with most traps without stepping on them even if they are between you and the path you need to go down, but there are still areas and configurations where they will always hit you, even if you try to disable them. Still holding my thumb up but sequels will need some tweaking.

Posted: April 12
Early Access Review
								Love the art style. I love this game so far but I think it feels a bit too plain and easy (not your normal rogue like). I know it's early access but there needs a variety of different enemies or different stats of enemies (say slimes... there should be fire, lava, water, etc slimes) I find myself running around and easily killing enemies. I should be afraid of the unknown not confident.And the traps are soooo soooo soooo obvious and visible. You can avoid it easily unless it's down a 1 block path. I think removing the huge plate and making it almost the same as the floor but different colour will make me not want to run around and be careful were I go.You can play all styles heavy warrior, archer, mage (no cast spells only wands I think. I haven't gotten far yet). The only enemies I encountered so far and I really hate that makes this game a bit challenging are those floating eyes of eyes that shoot burning balls. So op. I only find like 1-2 enemies each room. And that I can easily kill (again I haven't reached that far. I only reached ruins). If enemies were more difficult and more in numbers (could be a mod) I would love this game more.One last thing. All weapons and armors rings necklaces (foods?) Are all identified. Except for potions... I like the sense of having to be careful with everything you find and needing a scroll of identification to make sure the items are safe. (Cursed unfurled blessed etc). It made the game more challenging and a sense of wanting to beat the game. (I'm talking about nethack the origin of rogue likes ). So far I would recommend the game. I'm looking forward to the final product and hope they change it to the way I think it should be (or mods).

Posted: April 8
Early Access Review
								This is a fun, addicting game. I've barely had it for a day and I'm already hooked on it. There's plenty to explore, collect, loot, kill, and just look at. Given that this game is in Beta I believe, I'm expecting much more in the future. The pixelated art style is charming and adds a certain quality that makes it kind of light hearted and not too serious. That's also a good way to describe the game as well, since this game is pretty easy as far as Roguelikes go. The combat isn't anything special, but it's balanced and deep enough to keep it interesting while playing. I never found it to be tedious, and it was fun timing and landing charged attacks. The menus are a bit confusing though. Nothing really goes in depth in explaining them and I'm still not sure if I've got it all figured out. The default button for your inventory is "I" which is a bit out of the way and inconvenient considering that the main form of movement is WSAD. If there's more movement options or a way to change the controls, I am unaware of those at this time. Another problem I had with the menus was using items. There's no indication of what button does what, nor is there any explanation as to what anything does. I had a potion in my hot bar so I could drink it. Instead, I threw it on the ground, and it exploded. It took me a minute to realize that to use some items, you had to be in your inventory, which can be a hindrance in tense moments of battle where you need something from your inventory and quickly. There's definitely room for improvements to menu functionality and more, even if small and brief, tutorials. A note saying "Drink potions from your inventory and put them on your belt to throw them!" would be just fine. Other than those, this game is pretty solid and simple, and has room to expand upon in the future. If you're looking for your next short addiction (or maybe even a long one) this is a good game to look into.
